For example, the United States has used radioisotope thermoelectric generators, or RTGs, for earth observations in orbits generally greater than 700 kilometres. RTGs generally use plutonium 238 as a fuel source because of its high heat to mass ratio and relatively long half-life of 87.7 years. The natural orbit decay of these satellites is several hundred years, when they will re-enter the atmosphere and, as a result of friction in the air, burn up. This will, in most instances, turn the satellite into dust that will then be spread around by the wind and weather.

Both the United States and the former Soviet Union launched vehicles into space with RTGs as well as nuclear reactors using enriched uranium 235. We know that the US vehicles, which have re-entered the atmosphere, had RTGs that were encased so as to survive re-entry. All reports suggest that this was a successful design strategy, although I will comment more on that later. In contrast, the former Soviet Union designed their fuel sources to vaporise on re-entry.

The consequences of radioactive material spreading around the globe are frightening. The most important point to make here—and I will leave the details for another time—is that there is no safe dose of radioactivity, because the harmful effects of low dose radioactivity over generations cannot be presently determined and one `hit' is enough to cause cell damage that may lead to cancers. This means it is not acceptable to send radioactive material into space unless we have determined the risk and made a decision that it is a risk worth taking. Just because it is a low risk—and I say this to the smiling minister—does not necessarily mean it is a risk worth taking.

The next issue of concern to me is the increasing amount of what is broadly referred to as space debris. I would like to expand on this to talk about objects in space as being useful objects and as being debris. Whether you have the useful ones or the debris, it is all out there. Australia accounts for some 15 payloads and debris objects.
Senator Minchin interjecting—

talk.start.para: —I would very much like to hear the minister expand on his thoughts not only of space regulation but also about Australia's 15 payloads and space debris. The way this number is calculated is quite contentious. It should be seen as a relative number compared to the thousands of objects attributed to the United States, the former Soviet Union and the European Space Agency.

speech.para: This also means that Australia's contribution to space objects is a contribution to a fairly crowded space. It is a fairly crowded environment. The United States Space Command reports some 26,000 human-made objects in orbit which have been detected, tracked and catalogued. This number includes around 8½ thousand earth satellites. The rest are used rocket bodies, dead payloads and operational debris, which includes optic covers, attachment hardware and other bits and pieces which fall off vehicles.

Interestingly, only about six per cent of the 8½ thousand satellites are functioning. This does not include objects that are less than 10 centimetres in size in low earth orbit and up to one metre in geostationary orbits. This may amount to tens of thousands of objects. This is of significant concern, as these objects are likely to cause accidents and unexpected behaviour of space objects.

I have more to say about the specific purposes of this bill. My office received answers to questions about this bill quite late last night. Perhaps the minister will be happy to outline his responses to some of the concerns that were raised between our offices. I will be happy to address some of my concerns in relation to regulation versus self-regulation during the committee stage of this bill.

For the record, I do congratulate the new minister on his responsibilities, and I hope that he will bring vigour, a bit of passion as well as intellect to the debate not only about space but about science issues generally. I suggest that science is an area that has been sidelined by this parliament not just in recent history but by the previous government. I think that science issues are intimately linked with a range of portfolio areas like industry, training, education, research and information technologies—all these areas of the future which we should be considering as investments for future prosperity, be it economic as well as contributing to a society where we are more enlightened.

I think that science issues are not given the precedence that they often deserve in this place. It has been quite exciting to see a space bill on the Notice Paper for debate. I hope, Minister, that you will ensure that there are many more opportunities for discussion in this place about the crucial areas of science and technology.

talk.start.para: —I rise on behalf of the opposition to support this Space Activities Bill 1998 and do so with some pleasure as a former minister responsible for space activities from 1993 to 1996. It is a pleasure to see at long last a commercial development in space related activity taking place in Australia.

speech.para: I remember when I was the minister, when we were talking to the Kistler Corporation and others who may have been interested in using Australia as a launch site, that it was pointed out to me by the officers in the then Department of Industry, Science and Technology that this bill would be needed to provide a regulatory regime for commercial interest in space. I think I said I could accept that and I think at the time, informally, the department started to prepare what is now this bill, anticipating that we would be successful—after many trials and tribulations—in convincing some commercial organisation to use Australia as a launch site.

As a South Australian, I was particularly interested in getting Woomera reactivated because, in two years time with the closing of Nurrungar, Woomera will be basically wound down to being a care and maintenance operation of what 30 years ago was I think the third or fourth biggest town in South Australia. Woomera will be almost a ghost town of only a few hundred people on a care and maintenance basis for the Australian defence forces. In view of the taxpayers' contribution to build and establish Woomera over 50-odd years, it would be very sad—not only for South Australia but for Australia—to have Woomera wind down and allow it and a lot of facilities to basically disappear.

I did visit Woomera on a number of occasions as minister to look at what was already there in space related activity. I say to Senator Minchin—a fellow South Australian, as well as the minister—that it is instructive to go to Woomera and to go out to the various places where rockets used to be launched, as part of a military program by the British government in particular, in the fifties and the sixties. I am sure he, like me, would be staggered to see the investment that was made and the range of launch facilities that were built in that area, spread over many hundreds of square kilometres of Woomera and not just near the town. In fact, you have to drive 30 kilometres out in different directions to find some of them. In 1994 the command headquarters for launching rockets of a large nature, including the former ELDO rocket, was still in operational form. It had been maintained all those years waiting for the next rocket to be launched. Much of the equipment and the computers were outdated, but some had been upgraded. There was a care and maintenance operation. It was a two-storey building—more than a blockhouse arrangement—and it could be activated at very small extra cost.

It was also salutary to go and see at the edge of Island Lagoon the two sites the ELDO operation built in the late sixties to launch the European rockets before they were shifted for political reasons to French Guiana. We now find that that site in French Guiana is the most successful commercial rocket launching site in the world, regularly launching satellites every few weeks. That was a political decision the French forced on the ELDO operation under the wonders of General de Gaulle and we lost.

But, before it shifted, tens of millions of dollars were spent to build two major rocket launching facilities on the edge of the escarpment at the lagoon. One of them was used for static firings of the ELDO rocket and the other was never used at all. They had built the gantry that shifts the rockets to assemble the rockets; they had built all the ancillary equipment.

When I was space minister, it was most distressing for me to find that, in the late 1980s, one of these sites had been used by the SAS for target practice, to test gunfire power and to conduct explosives tests. They blew the roof off the underground control bunker with explosive devices as an experiment. That concrete structure, which is equivalent to 10-storeys high, is pockmarked with every type of light to middle level armament. There are shell holes all over it. All the concrete observation posts built around the edge of the site from which the observers watched rockets take off have shell marks all over them.

I took the matter up with my colleague the Minister for Defence so as to stop the SAS, or any other Defence operation, continuing to blow up these assets because, in that period, we had invited a delegation from various Russian rocket making companies to visit. They said that the shell of the site which had not been blown up could be used, with very cheap modification, to launch modified proton rockets. I think we got agreement that they would no longer use the ELDO concrete site for target practice and that the SAS would no longer use it to test explosive devices.

All over Woomera there are sites for launching very small rockets up to the size of the ELDO. The major advantage of Woomera is that it is a declared area for defence purposes, and it covers many thousands of square kilometres. It would be nice if it was closer to the Equator because we could launch equatorial rockets. Commercially, it is cheaper the closer you get to the Equator. But, for a north-south polar orbit, Woomera is very well placed to launch rockets with low earth orbiting satellites for communication purposes. I think that is what the Kistler organisation is looking at.

I think I can mention now for the benefit of the minister that the Russians told us it is possible to assemble and fire these rockets from Australia for as little as $10 million a firing, which is extremely cheap. The Russians provided drawings. We brought a Russian delegation to Australia and they were amazed at what we had at Woomera but also, when we took them through the submarine corporation engineering works at Pooraka—not at Osborne—they said the equipment the submarine corporation had at those engineering works was capable of being used for assembling rockets. The equipment and the technology was available then.

In the early 1990s Transfield was interested in putting together a consortium to launch rockets from Australia. As John White, the former head of Transfield, said, making and launching a rocket from Australia is a lot less complicated than building an Anzac frigate in Williamstown. It is not that difficult. We used the old saying that you must be a rocket scientist. But this is not rocket science. By using that phrase we made rocket science sound a lot more complicated and expensive than it now is.

I say to the minister that I ran into trouble when trying to convince Treasury and Finance to make money available to seed fund and initiate space related activities in Australia. I think my colleagues in the Treasury and Defence bureaucracies believed I was trying to build Cape Canaveral at Woomera. All I was after was a few million dollars over five years to kick-start something that would be, in the end, a value added industry.

As Senator Stott Despoja pointed out, in Australia we probably import now about $1 billion worth of services from space satellites. That goes on our current account deficit. If we are serious about getting the current account deficit down, in the long run we will have to look at areas where we think we can reduce those import costs. One of those areas is through space related activities.

If we launch satellites, we can then leverage the service that goes on the satellite because that can be provided to Australia at a cheaper price since we are actually launching it. I have to say that Treasury and Finance did not accept that argument and did everything possible to say that that is not what the free market is about, et cetera.

Let me tell you that space is not about the free market. Everything in space is about a controlled, fixed, rigged market. When I was dealing with the Russians or the Americans, they were always leveraging it to make commercial advantage for their nations. We should not be naive enough to believe we will get any advantage without leveraging our geographical and geopolitical position in the world. Australia is very well placed to be a major launch site, but it will need a commitment.

I have to say that this bill is an excellent start. I suggest, Minister, that there will be some issues debated in committee and some amendments may be moved. I have no doubt that, within two or three years, you will be back here to amend this bill to expand the regulatory regime and, I would hope, to put in place a more proactive industry policy to provide value adding space related activities from Australia—and, I have to say, from South Australia in particular. I think the Kistler beginning is an excellent one.

Minister, I know that you inherited this portfolio and that decisions were taken in the last three years about the funding of space activities. I have to say that, although I was not successful in growing the space budget, I was able to hang on and maintain in it at least a few million dollars. In the first term of your government the decision to abolish the Australian Space Office and the funding that went with it for some proactive research was a mistake. In industry policy terms, it was about leveraging value added for Australia. I am pleased to see that at least you have put some money back to administer the regulatory regime. But in the estimates committee to come in February, I will take that opportunity to have more of a dialogue about developing space related activities.

You will never get commercial development to the level of value adding the best jobs unless the federal government of Australia is seen worldwide as being genuinely interested and willing to put some money up-front as seed money for R&D and some infrastructure development. This legislation will be a good message to start off with. I am not suggesting that you need $50 million, $100 million or $500 million. You may need a few tens of millions over five years to target where you need the development of space related activities. If we are serious about creating high quality jobs, reducing our current account deficit and space related activities, this is the place where we can do it without a major cost to the Australian taxpayer.

Regarding the development of low earth orbiting satellite networks for telecommunications, we have seen the advertisements on television that the Iridium network is now up and running. This is the start of what we ought to be able to say to Iridium and to Motorola. Every year they are going to have to launch replacement low earth orbiting satellites. We should be able to say, whether to Kistler or someone else, `We can launch these from Australia on a regular basis at a cheap price'. Bill Gates, under his program, believes he can deliver the information superhighway by a network of 900 low earth orbiting satellites. Nine hundred would mean that, every year, 40 or 50 would have to be replaced. Some will fall to earth, some will hit each other and some will not work. So there has to be a replacement.

What we have to aim for, in my view, is getting the commercial operators to see that we can effectively launch these satellites. Once we get into that, we can then start leveraging back and asking, `What are we going to do to build the satellite?' We already have people in this country who have won contracts to provide parts to American satellites that are now operating in space, either militarily or for commercial reasons. In this very town of Canberra there are people who have successfully made parts—major and significant parts—for American satellites for various commercial companies. That ought to be built upon. That is why we need an industry policy, an industry plan—not a plan to give a free kick or for someone to grab $50 million, put it into their pocket, disappear and then, after five years, say, `Thank you very much. Give us another $50 million'. We need a dedicated plan to leverage the opportunities we already have—the skill we already have.

I read only last week in the Business Review Weekly—and I draw this to the minister's attention—a story about the next generation of jetliners that will actually go through the edge of space, supersonic, to London in two hours. What are they talking about? One of the jet engines compresses gas, or oxygen, at high speed and at a high speed it combusts and provides power. The leading proponent of that technology over the last 10 years is from Queensland University. All they needed for that program was funding from time to time of a few hundred thousand dollars. They have the worldwide leadership in it. They need to test the equipment. They need to put up a test probe on a satellite with a model to show that it actually works.

If we get into the league, we have the control of the technology; we have the knowledge and the skill. We will not have to spend hundreds of millions of dollars. Others will come and say, `We want you to be the partner because you have the skill. You have the intellectual property'. That is how I see an effective, subtle, discreet program operating, because we have the intellectual knowledge already in this country if we can put it together with a focused program.

Although I have not spoken much on this bill, because I agree with it—and the opposition agrees with it—we see this as the very first small step of what some of us tried to do in the early 1990s as the opportunities arose. There are companies in Australia, given the right leadership, that will invest. There are overseas companies that will invest. The jobs that will come, and the quality of those jobs, will mean that we have a real advantage in this country, in our national interest as well as in our commercial interest.

Minister, I urge you to go and visit Woomera and have a look at the site. You will, like me, be a little dismayed at what we have allowed to be destroyed. I ran across an Indian space engineer who skited that, when we wound down ELDO and so on, we sold all our best space equipment to India at give-away prices. They used it to build their own space equipment. They have their own rocket now, built on cheap equipment they bought from Australia in the 1960s and 1970s when we gave away Woomera and the equipment at peppercorn prices.

The saga of space in Australia now is a very sorry saga of many lost opportunities. I hope this bill, in a sense of bipartisanship, is the beginning of an opportunity that we are not going to lose—that we see it as the beginning of an opportunity and build upon it. Therefore, I commend the bill to the Senate. I look forward to taking part in the committee stage, if there are further amendments. Minister, I ask you whether at the committee stage you can give any further indication of allocation of extra resources to the space program. I will take that up with you in the estimates committee as well. I look forward, as I say, to further debate in this chamber about establishing a decent Australian space program.
Debate (on motion by Senator Minchin) adjourned.

talk.start.para: —Order! It being 12.45 p.m., we will now proceed to matters of public interest.
—I rise today to talk about the importance of community sport and recreation and, in particular, what will happen when the 2000 Olympics are over.

speech.para: The course this government is charting is based on providing for elite sport above all else. They have shifted the balance such that grassroots sports and recreational activities are being ignored in favour of medal winning sports. We have seen cuts right across the sporting budget in the last two coalition budgets and inevitably, as that pool of funding diminishes, community and participatory sports programs receive less and less resources. Yes, the Olympics are important—but so too is the local netball court, public pool, athletics track and recreational fishing day.

Under this government, Australia's reputation as an egalitarian society where everybody gets `a fair go' no longer applies. It no longer applies because this government cannot see beyond a bandaid solution of short-term funding. There is no depth to their policy and no strategy that has Australia's future in mind. Because sports funding is increasingly being directed away from grassroots and community based participation towards elite programs, in an ever-diminishing pool of funding, there is now an even greater need for government involvement in the promotion of participation.

Regrettably, the government has to date ignored some of the critical recommendations contained in the report prepared during its period of government entitled Rethinking the funding of community sporting and recreational facilities: a sporting chance. It has failed to act on some of the report's critical recommendations. Certainly, sport has changed. It is now big business and the corporate dollar that largely shapes competitive sport. It is the sponsorship dollar that determines whether or not a sport survives. If you want an example: here in the ACT our women's cricket team had to clean out the amenities at Manuka Oval during the men's one day game, so that they could raise enough money for an interstate visit. Without sponsorship or funding, the non-elite side of sport suffers.

Just look at how sports competitions are declining in many regional areas because transport and registration costs are becoming prohibitive. Rural and regional communities are really doing it tough under the Howard government. We have seen this across a whole range of policy areas. And the one thing that many small towns have to alleviate the many stresses of life—sport—has become a discretionary cost that fewer and fewer families can afford.

What happened to sport and recreation as simply a means of enjoyment and exercise? What is the government doing to ensure that participation is increased and that facilities are available to anyone who wants to improve their health?

If the government wants the low-down on the role sport plays in Australian life, they should take a careful look at the Confederation of Australian Sports study, the Economic Impact Study of Sport. The Confederation's report highlights the tremendous contribution the sports sector makes to Australian society. In the 1995-96 financial year, the sports sector was worth almost $8 billion and sports related exports contributed over $430 million. Australian households spend around $6 billion each year on sport and recreation, meaning that sport brings in about the same economic benefits as the car, clothing and electricity industry sectors.

You would think that the government would recognise the economic benefits by supporting the sports industry. You would think that an industry that employs close to 100,000 people, as well as engaging almost 850,000 volunteers, would be deserving of a long-term commitment from the coalition. But their record to date shows that this is not the case.

By the year 2000 to 2001, the Howard government will reduce its financial commitment to sport by over $60 million. The Howard government is happy to take almost a billion dollars in taxation generated from the sports sector, but they will not provide any real commitment beyond the Olympic Games. So when the games are over and the big sponsorship dollars have moved on to Athens, Australia is going to be left without adequate funding for elite and community sport programs and participation rates will drop even further.

The government's approach to sport is a short-term strategy—if you could call it a strategy at all. It is bereft of any vision about the important role sport and physical activity will play in our future. And, outside of some cheerleading about the Olympics, I have heard nothing about addressing the fundamentals of physical fitness and recreational sport and the role that that has in the quality of the lives of Australians.

The report of the Confederation of Australian Sport, which presents a snapshot of the nation's health, acknowledges the importance of participation. Unfortunately, we are more of a nation of sports watchers than sports participants. In 1995-96, just over 30 per cent of Australians participated in some form of physical activity. That means that over 4½ million Australians were involved in either a playing or non-playing capacity—but it also means that nearly 70 per cent of adults were not involved. One of the most important statistics to emerge is that a five per cent increase in the participation rate in sport would deliver a net economic benefit of over $800 million to the Australian economy. In other words, if the government bothered to invest in sport and recreation—rather than slashing away at the budget allocations and funding—then they might be surprised to find that the rewards far outweigh the investment.

The benefits of increased participation are tangible right across the board. A healthier society means a healthier work force. And we know that there is a direct correlation between increased health and fitness and increased productivity and occupational health and safety standards. Conversely, people who are not fit—and less healthy—take more sick days. They are less productive and have greater occupational health problems.

So increased community participation in sport and recreation creates greater income for governments and delivers tangible benefits in terms of workplace productivity and safety. Some of these equations represent a correlation of figures that is not currently taken into account in the government's assessments of where they should put resources. It is the blend of looking at these cross-portfolio areas and their interrelationships that becomes so critical in policy development in this area.

What the statistics do not tell us, however, is how many people are unable to participate. Statistics do not tell us about people excluded from participation because of structural and economic barriers that this government has done nothing about. They have not done anything about increasing participation, because this is part of the unglamorous side of sport. You will not find the Prime Minister or the minister for sport addressing barriers faced by sections of the community who want nothing more than the chance to participate in some form of recreational activity.

You will not see them out there talking up Paralympic sport with the same gusto as non-Paralympic sport. The Australian Paralympic Committee received just $1 million from the Olympic program—or just four per cent of sports funding in Australia. This pitiful amount of money is hardly recognition for the 42 gold medals, 37 silver medals and 27 bronze medals Australia won at the Atlanta Paralympic Games. Yet, in many ways, it is more important to fund programs for people with disabilities, as their ability to participate is often dependent on government provided infrastructure. And the opportunity to participate in those programs presents the first opportunity for them to just participate in physical activity from a grassroots perspective.

There are too many barriers to participation—barriers such as lack of public transport to venues; lack of facilities for athletes with disabilities; inadequate lighting of grounds and car parks, which is a real concern particularly for women and children; lack of change rooms and toilets, especially wheelchair access; lack of adequate child care; and lack of quality public facilities.

So how do we redress the barriers that are preventing more Australians from pursuing a healthier lifestyle? There obviously is not some magic formula that will automatically make us a fit and healthy nation, but slashing funding and cutting critical government programs are certainly not the answer. What can be done is to look at those sections of Australia where participation is low and then to examine what resources and facilities are available. And what you will find is that, while some regions and urban centres are well catered for, others compete for scarce resources.

It is amazing what a decent football field or basketball court or soccer pitch with a clubhouse and change rooms can do for the physical, mental and economic health of a community. The government might be surprised to learn that the health and wellbeing of all Australians is what counts, not just that of certain sections favoured by this administration.

One of the reasons that we must enhance and broaden the participation rate is that sport acts as a coalescing force. It binds people together; it gives them a sense of purpose, a sense of place and a sense of community. For many residents of rural Australia, sport is one of the few things that keeps their communities alive. The banks might be gone, the Internet might be unaffordable, pay TV might never arrive—but sport is always going to be there.

Governments understand this—or at least they should. They understand it when they underwrite international sporting events, but this government have shown that they do not understand that by investing in people, by investing in grassroots sport and recreation, they will get a far greater return than just the financial revenue.

talk.start.para: —During the last sitting of the Senate, I spoke on the audit report on the health of Aboriginal communities. I spoke about my concerns in this regard and particularly about the death of one Aboriginal woman. Today I want to speak a little more about that situation today and to commend the Courier-Mail in Brisbane which, through the offices of one its journalists, Tony Koch, has been exposing some of the tragic circumstances which do exist on Aboriginal communities in Queensland.

speech.para: I also want to speak about a great friend of mine, Francis Yunkaporta, who died a few weeks ago on the Aurukun community and whose funeral was attended by many people from around this country, including Minister Herron. I certainly commend him for that.

Francis Yunkaporta was a very highly respected Wik elder who died of cancer on Thursday 29 October without seeing justice in his lifelong battle for his people to own and manage their traditional land. His death follows that of many other Wik warriors, but particularly people such as John Koowarta. It represents the loss of one of the most respected and trusted leaders of the Wik people.

White missionaries took Francis and his father from the family's home at Cape Keer Weer to the Aurukun mission on the western side of Cape York Peninsula when Francis was only six years old. His father was removed in chains. When Francis' father reached Aurukun and realised his children were being taken from him, he protested and tangled physically with the superintendent, but he was chained up again and thrown onto a barge which took him back to Cape Keer Weer.
Francis never saw his mother again. He did see his father, although they never discussed the day the children were taken. In reference to his father, Francis says in his autobiography:
He never talked about the day I was taken from him but I could tell he was crying inside when he thought about it.
This was reported to John Camplin in 1993, who wrote an article about it then.

Francis went on from mission life to join the Australian Army's Light Horse Brigade, and then after the war worked as a stockman on stations around Cape York for 15 years before getting married in Aurukun. Francis was separated from his wife for a year when he was sent to the penal settlement at Palm Island for protesting when a white official at Aurukun pointed a gun at one of his friends.

In 1968, Francis was elected Chairman of the Mission Council Board and embarked on a 30-year career as a powerful leader of the Wik people. During this time Francis became involved with the Presbyterian—now Uniting—Church, which administered the Aurukun and Mornington Island mission stations. His first major battle came 10 years later in 1978 when the then Joh Bjelke-Petersen government instructed the church to quit Aurukun in order to allow Comalco to begin mining a massive bauxite deposit found on Wik land.

Francis was the main media spokesman during the dispute that followed, which involved former Prime Minister Malcolm Fraser and federal Aboriginal Affairs minister Ian Viner. It became not only a dispute between Aboriginal people and the state government but also a dispute between the Commonwealth government and the state government at the time. Francis also worked within the church to win support for his people in this particular struggle. Francis did not, however, have the total support of all church leaders, as he found out when he travelled to Brisbane to attend a special synod to discuss management of Aboriginal reserves at Aurukun and Mornington Island.

At this time I was very much personally involved with him and with other leaders. I remember the impact that he made on the Uniting Church Synod over a number of years as he attended the synod and engaged in the debates. The synod was, as you can imagine, divided along political lines—the idea that politics does not enter religion is something that only someone who does not know anything about it would believe—on the question of whether to agree to hand over administration of the Aurukun and Mornington Island missions to the state government.

Francis sat quietly in the synod while church leader after church leader argued the fate of his people. I remember that he walked quietly to the podium and spoke for about five minutes in his traditional Wik language. It was very powerful, because he then translated what he had said into English. I am quoting from memory, but he said something like: `You have all been debating the future of my people as if you understand us, but I wonder if you do. I am speaking now in your language, but did you understand when I spoke to you in my language?' It was a powerful moment. He then went on to talk about the struggle of the Wik people over the years and of his hope that the church would come to support them in their fight for self-determination in the coming years. Francis Yunkaporta's Christian faith was critical to his fight for the Wik people.

I remember when the Aurukun people opened the Wik summit which was held in Cairns in January just two years ago. Francis and other people from Aurukun opened proceedings with a special ceremony. They planted a symbol of traditional Aboriginal law and then they sang a hymn which contained the words: We love the land, oh God, wherein thine honour dwells. They explained that their Christian faith and their traditional law guaranteed for them that God resided in their traditional land and that that meant, from the point of view of both their faith and their law, they had no choice but to protect and fight for that land. This approach was typical of Francis Yunkaporta. Throughout his life, no matter how often governments, churches, mining companies or whoever dished out poor treatment to his people, he always maintained a quiet reserve and stated his case simply and with great dignity.

Francis Yunkaporta was one of the most gracious men I have ever known. He possessed great leadership and wisdom. He gave his community stability and leadership throughout the turbulent sixties, seventies and eighties, and even into the 1990s.

He was among a contingent of Wik people who travelled to Canberra for the third passage of the Wik legislation through the Senate this year. He watched while Senator Harradine danced with some of his people. The tragedy is that Aboriginal elders like Francis Yunkaporta are now deceased. The Wik warriors before him who tried to get justice through the white system are dying without seeing justice done. That causes me great pain.

I visited Aurukun just a few weeks ago. I must say, having visited Aurukun over the last 20 years and having had close connections with many of the people, that I was distressed to see the condition of the community and to read again some of the stories—not only of that community but of other communities on Cape York—that have been collected by Tony Koch and repeated in the Brisbane Courier-Mail. The horror of the situation at Aurukun and other Aboriginal communities has been highlighted through those reports; communities are racked by violence, alcohol abuse and despair. I commend the Courier-Mail for having the courage to tell those stories. I also commend the previous Governor of Queensland, Leneen Forde, who has taken up this particular cause and had some public meetings about it. She intends to pursue the issue. She is a great woman and a great Queenslander. She was also, I must say, a great governor. I commend her for the initiative that she has taken.

Those reports in the Courier-Mail are a sad chronicle of lives destroyed by solvable problems. Even more tragic are the reports in the last few days that public servants responsible for the Cape York communities reported this over 10 years ago and cried out for solutions. But action was not taken by governments of any colour. Women and children have been needlessly brutalised over these many years. I commend Tony Koch on his reports and the Courier-Mail for running them, but I wonder what they will achieve. I guess this is the point of my speaking here today.

There is community sympathy right now in Queensland. The state government has promised more dollars and an indigenous women's task force to look at the problems—and that is great. However, the Democrats think that the problems are too complex to tie down to just the state government. I believe that there are many other people who are and ought to be involved. Certainly the community councils should be involved.

I remember many years ago going to the then minister, Russell Hinze, with a request from the council of Aurukun at that time that they have the ability to pass by-laws making Aurukun a dry community. The minister at the time was unable or unwilling to allow that to happen. The community councils have a responsibility. The women in these communities also need to have a voice, because it is they who are most affected by the violence and the abuse of alcohol. It also comes down to money being provided for proper refuges for those women and children, and whether money is getting through to where it is needed. It comes down to looking at our priorities. I realise that at this moment we are spending millions of dollars on an indigenous arts festival for the Olympics when Aboriginal women and children are cringing in fear of violent men in their communities in refuges that are shot through with bullet holes. That is the reality. It comes down to providing economic futures for remote indigenous communities. That is critical.

Francis Yunkaporta rose from a community racked by despair and violence and managed to be a voice of dignity and reason for his people. But the elders are dying out and many of the young people are in despair. If massive cultural and economic change is not wrought in Aboriginal Australia, and if great leaders like Francis Yunkaporta do not come forward, then I fear for the future.

talk.start.para: —I rise today in this matter of public interest debate to address the issue of the by- election on 5 December in the state of Queensland in the state seat of Mulgrave. The seat is currently held by One Nation. That should not be the case, but it is.

speech.para: The Nationals had the opportunity to place One Nation last on their preference ticket at the forthcoming by-election. Whilst it is optional preferential voting, the Nationals chose not to place One Nation last but to leave it to the voters to choose where to allocate their preferences. Whilst this might be something that can happen—and reasonably so under normal circumstances—one would have hoped that a more responsible attitude would have been adopted by the National Party in this by-election on 5 December.
Mr Borbidge, the Leader of the National Party and the opposition, hates both Labor and One Nation, and therefore hates to give—
Senator Woodley interjecting—

talk.start.para: —You could say that. He refuses to put Labor ahead of One Nation. He has left it up to the voters and to whatever might happen on the day. This is politically irresponsible. It shows why the Nationals are in the trouble that they are in today, both in Queensland and nationally.

speech.para: One Nation raised its head to satisfy the disenchanted voter out there, and they have had some success—no more so than in Queensland. None of this would have happened in the first place in the state of Queensland if Mr Howard had accepted Mr Beazley's challenge and delivered a decisive blow early on in the piece to One Nation. There is no doubt that, if the ALP challenge that was put out as early as June 1997 that One Nation should be placed last—and which was denied by the Prime Minister—had been taken up, One Nation would never ever have got a leg off the ground. That was the morally appropriate action to take, rather than allow One Nation to bubble along and rise to the prominence that they now have. Some may argue that that prominence is on the wane, but I will come to that in a few moments. The fact is that, by failing to address the issue early on, the Prime Minister failed badly.

We saw that outcome in the Queensland election in June 1998. The coalition failed badly in failing to put One Nation last. They showed a complete lack of understanding of the political consequences of their decision not to put One Nation last. What we saw was political expediency above principle. In my estimation, the adoption of that position, together with the accelerated pace of change by the Howard government over the last 2½ years, brought about the undoing of the coalition in Queensland.

There were harsh initiatives by the Howard government—cuts to legal aid and removal of free job services such as the CES, disastrous policies on aged care and a loss of interest in rural and regional areas. All this fuelled the One Nation fire and contributed to the problems suffered by the National Party and its ultimate demise in Queensland.

The coalition in Queensland then went on to legitimise One Nation not only as a party but as a voice in the parliament of Queensland. Of course, this then further legitimised that party in Australian politics.

Labor's decision to put One Nation last in that state election held in June this year saved nine coalition seats—nine seats throughout the state of Queensland which would have been lost if Labor had otherwise directed its preferences went to the coalition because Labor put One Nation last. Conversely, though, the coalition's decision to put One Nation ahead of Labor caused One Nation to win eight seats. One Nation, of course, directed preferences to the coalition in 15 seats and saved at least four National Party seats.

If that series of events had not taken place, firstly, we would not have One Nation as a force to be reckoned with in Queensland and Australian politics to the extent that they have to be reckoned with today. Secondly, we would not be facing the prospect of One Nation being re-elected in the seat of Mulgrave in the by-election on 5 December if firm action had been taken in the first place. If Labor had not put principle before political expediency in Queensland, then the One Nation numbers in the state parliament in Queensland could have been 20. In that case, One Nation would have been larger than both the National Party and the Liberal Party. What a set of circumstances would have unfolded then. Instead of Mr Borbidge and Mr Beattie vying for the right to form government we would have seen the Governor talking to Mr Feldman during that period of uncertainty. Of course, history now shows that Mr Beattie was successful in forming a Labor government—and a good one at that.

Whilst One Nation did not win a House of Representatives seat, it did win a Senate seat in Queensland. It cannot be said that One Nation is a spent force and that One Nation is on the wane. Whilst in the recent Newcastle election held last Saturday there was no Liberal or National Party candidate, One Nation did come second on the poll, well ahead of the Greens, who got nine per cent, and the Democrats, who got eight per cent. They achieved 16 per cent of the primary vote in that election held in the seat of Newcastle. Whilst one cannot read great things into this, it certainly dispels the theory that they are on the wane. If they were not to be a force in Australian politics, why didn't the Greens or the Democrats perform significantly better? They did not. The fact remains that the One Nation candidate did poll nearly 17 per cent of the primary vote with nearly 80 per cent of the vote counted.

I think it is a miscalculation to say that One Nation is a spent force. Given the opportunity to deliver a telling blow to One Nation in the forthcoming by-election in the state seat of Mulgrave, the National Party have whimped it, in my view. They had the opportunity to come out decisively by clearly putting One Nation last but, by not putting One Nation last and by equivocating, the coalition have left the door open for One Nation to succeed for a second time in the electorate. That is a frightening prospect indeed. Having succeeded once was bad enough, but to have a second bite of the cherry—or the apple—is unforgivable. The Nationals could be going down the path of further cementing the legitimacy given to One Nation by them on the previous occasion.

For the record, in the Queensland election on the last occasion Labor got 44, the Nationals got 23, One Nation got 11, the Liberals got nine and the Independents got two. It was on that basis that Labor was able to form a government with the assistance of one of the Independents and, whilst it is not in government in its own right, Labor still is the government in the state of Queensland.

The Nationals putting One Nation last will not in any way alter the state of play in the state of Queensland in the by-election on Saturday, 5 December. The result will not change who is in government. It would, therefore, have been a move showing real leadership and real courage for the National Party to have come out decisively and put One Nation last on the ballot paper, giving a clear preference direction to the people of Queensland, showing that not only is their rhetoric strong by having some of their representatives against the One Nation cause but that, in fact, they also back it up by putting One Nation last.

The fact is they did not; they fell at the hurdle again. So what we are faced with in the by-election in the state of Queensland on Saturday the 5th is not just getting One Nation elected for the first time but getting One Nation elected for the second time. I believe that the National Party should have shown the courage of their convictions and should have stood up and been counted on this issue by placing One Nation last. They failed to do so.

I have an ongoing concern that One Nation, with their flat earth policies, can in any way gain any legitimacy in Australian politics. Whilst I disagree with most of the views of the people opposite and of some of the other people in this chamber, that does not mean that they are the total anathema that the One Nation views are. One would hope that, if confronted by this again, the Nationals will clearly put One Nation last.

talk.start.para: —In today's matters of public interest debate, I will seek to highlight the benefits to all Australians, and in particular to my fellow Tasmanians, that will flow from the government's election commitment to provide a 30 per cent rebate for those that insure for their health needs.

speech.para: Health and health care are important concerns for many Australians; they want choice and they want a fair system. In response to community concern, the government announced its policy of a 30 per cent rebate on health insurance premiums. The government was elected on that policy. Yet I understand that there are now elements within this chamber who would seek to frustrate the implementation of this sound social policy—indeed, people who were elected on the promise to the Australian people that they would hold the government accountable for the promises it made.

You know the slogan `Keeping the bastards honest'? Well, there are certain elements in this Senate that are deliberately seeking to ensure that the government cannot abide by its election promises, by abusing the power they hold in this place to frustrate the wishes of the government. They seem to be hell-bent on frustrating the wishes of the Australian people and what is a very sound social policy. Recently I received a well-documented submission from the Tasmanian Private Hospitals Association. It contained a wealth of information. It ought to be compulsory reading for any senator but in particular for Tasmanian senators thinking of opposing this important reform.

Almost half of the private hospitals in this country are not-for-profit hospitals run by church and charitable organisations, or are charity based. They provide a welfare support role way beyond the point of discharge, which includes a significant range of social services, research and general preventative health education services. All of those would be at risk if our policies are not adopted.

It should also be noted that most of the health insurance funds are not-for-profit organisations. Latest research indicates that every one per cent drop in membership of the private health funds incurs an $83 million funding increase in commitment by state treasuries to the public hospital system. If the number of policy holders were to drop by two per cent per year in the next three years, the government would have to find another $500 million per annum for the states to maintain the status quo. The simple fact is that having people in private health insurance, having health insurance cover, takes the burden off the public sector. By pursuing what could only be some ideological motivation in trying to frustrate the government's policy, what they are in fact doing means that there will be a greater pressure on the public health system, which is already moaning and groaning under the weight of waiting lists.

It is not generally appreciated that while 91 per cent of funding for public hospitals comes from all taxpayers, 94 per cent of private hospital funding, which is about $3.5 billion, is self-funded: it comes from patient user premium charges. In other words, those who are treated by the private hospital system pay twice for hospital services in Australia: compulsorily, as general taxpayers, for the public system; and, by exercising freedom of choice, by paying yet again by means of premium and user charges to be treated in a private hospital as against a public hospital.

Those patients who take responsibility for financing their own health care needs by choosing to use the service of a private hospital directly forgo their Medicare entitlements under the public health system. In real terms, this exercise of choice equates to a private subsidy of Medicare of around $2.6 billion per year which in fact—and this is interesting—is more than double the proposed rebate put forward by the federal government, and thus allows the public hospital system to cater for the more needy members of the community.

The private hospital system makes a very significant contribution to Australia's public welfare and health system. Its hospitals treated 1.77 million people last year, which equates to 33 per cent of all admissions, and directly employed in its 472 hospitals 41,918 full-time equivalent staff. If suppliers and contractors are added, private hospital services represent an aggregate employment sector of 100,000 Australians and their families. It is noteworthy to remind ourselves that health insurance is accessed by 700,000 Australians earning less than $20,000 per annum, so private health insurance is hardly the play ground for the rich that the opposition is seeking to portray it as.

The Liberal rebate would inject an additional $8 million in disposable income into each federal electorate which, on average, contains 39,000 insured adults and children. Those federal members thinking of voting against this proposal should be giving serious consideration to what they are going to tell those 39,000 adults and children in their electorate as to why they do not want to assist them. Also, they might like to tell the small business owners in their electorate why they did not want that extra $8 million of disposable income in the pockets of their electors. The only reason that could motivate people would be an outdated ideological mind-set.

If the health insurance system were to collapse, not only would these 39,000 people in each electorate suffer but it would place an intolerable burden on the public health system, with governments being forced to provide an additional 25,000 beds in the public system, involving greater capital outlays and a recurrent cost of an extra $3 billion per year.

If that scenario is not bad enough, it is even worse for my home state of Tasmania. Tasmania has a markedly higher private health coverage than the mainland states. In the June 1998 quarter, 30.6 per cent of Australians had private health insurance, with the Tasmanian rate being 33.5 per cent.
Senator Watson interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Senator John Watson has just interjected and made the very telling point that in Tasmania, in fact, we have the lowest rate of disposable income of any state, which, of course, confirms yet again the need for this rebate and blasts out of the water the mantra from the ALP and those that would oppose this rebate that somehow health insurance is the playground for the rich. In fact, it is a need for those who have health insurance. In the two years to June 1998, 19,000 Tasmanians have dropped out of private health cover, which unfortunately constitutes 10.8 per cent of total membership. Such a transfer of patient responsibility from the private to the public hospital sector will inevitably result in increased waiting lists, which are already high, and those who come from Tasmania would be aware of the very real difficulties being experienced by both the previous and current government in trying to make ends meet in relation to the public hospital sector.

speech.para: On top of that, Tasmanians suffer worse health than the citizens of any other state or territory and our demographic profile is the most vulnerable of all the states because we have a pronounced ageing population which will require increasing medical attention as the years go by and, quite frankly, Tasmania of all the states is least capable of financially meeting the challenge. Tasmanians rely more on the private hospital system than any other state. The issue of assisting people to retain or rejoin health insurance funds enjoys overwhelming support.

Some people have sought to use a perverted sense of the term `social justice' in this debate, but let me just remind them that social justice is not based on an outdated dogma, nor is it based on jealousy or a desire to cut down tall poppies. True social justice seeks to look after all. When you have got a situation where, as I have mentioned before, 700,000 Australians are in private health insurance who earn less than $20,000 per annum it ought to make people think.

talk.start.para: —They are not rich.

—As Senator Watson quite rightly interjects, they are not rich. But what is the Labor Party's policy for those? It is simply to block our measure. That is all they can do because, on the other side, they are unfortunately a policy-free zone.

speech.para: Allow me to go through this question of social justice. Looked at in isolation, the rebate may appear inequitable because of the lack of a means test. However, when high income earners drop their cover and compete for public hospital beds, the relative tax burden on low and middle income earners increases and the access to public hospitals of those who can never afford the private system is impaired; and that is the social justice issue in this debate.

The context is, I suppose, that Medicare is not means tested. The rebate encourages the better off to contribute to their own health care costs, leaving the public system better placed to provide health services to the needy. That is social justice in anybody's language. This is an equitable outcome.

The $1.3 billion expended on the rebate will produce more care in the longer run than $1.3 billion spent in public hospitals because individuals have shown time and time again that they will make a contribution to their own health care in return for choice of provider and choice of institution.

The key to all this is to use the subsidy judiciously so that the personal financial contribution is a reasonable one. I still recall in the previous government when a certain Prime Minister bragged about the fact that he did not have private health insurance. But take the tip: when he or his family were in need of health care in a hospital, do you think they were required to wait in the overcrowded waiting rooms? Of course not. They were allowed to pass through and get immediate service. That is not social justice. That is not fair, especially in circumstances when there was the capacity to pay for their own private health insurance.

My plea is in particular to my fellow Tasmanians to consider this issue very carefully and to my fellow senators from Tasmania to consider this issue very carefully because, if this rebate proposal is lost, the greatest losers will be the people of Tasmania, who have the highest rate of health insurance combined with the lowest income combined with the greatest health needs of this country. I simply ask them: put away the silly ideological dogma or hang-up and look after the people of Tasmania on this very important issue.

talk.start.para: —The issue that I wish to make some comments on today concerns the matter of dual citizenship and eligibility for standing for public office. The matter has been in the media once again, with some allegations being made against Senator-elect Heather Hill from Queensland, who is scheduled to take her position on 1 July next year.

speech.para: Firstly, it is useful, by way of background, to have a very brief overview of the issue in respect to section 44(i) of the constitution, which provides that:
Any person who-

(i) Is under any acknowledgment of allegiance, obedience, or adherence to a foreign power, or is a subject or a citizen or entitled to the rights or privileges of a subject or a citizen of a foreign power: . . .
shall be incapable of being chosen or of sitting as a senator or a member of the House of Representatives.

Section 44(i) was involved fairly recently, on 25 November 1992, in a decision of the High Court in a case that was known as Sykes v. Cleary. This matter has been widely reported on occasions since November 1992. In that case of Sykes v. Cleary, six of the seven judges of the High Court found Mr Cleary incapable of being chosen or of sitting as a member of parliament on the grounds that he had held an office of profit under the Crown under section 44(iv) of the constitution and, as a result, the by-election was void. Interestingly, Mr Cleary went on to be re-elected to parliament. The electors made a clear statement about what they thought about this issue.

The same case involved consideration of section 44(i) of the constitution. A majority of five to two of the High Court found that two other candidates, Mr Kardamitsis and Mr Delacretaz, were ineligible under section 44(i) and, therefore, a recount could not be conducted. All seven judges found that section 44(i) required a person to take all reasonable steps to renounce their other citizenship.

The majority of the court held that this required use of the renunciation procedures of the other country if there were such procedures. Where there were no such procedures, or where the other country refused renunciation, proof of requesting renunciation was sufficient. Because such procedures were available in relation to the two countries of which Mr Kardamitsis and Mr Delacretaz were citizens, they had not taken all reasonable steps to renounce and were therefore ineligible under section 44(i). Two judges dissented on the section 44(i) point and considered that Mr Kardamitsis and Mr Delacretaz had taken all reasonable steps by making oaths of allegiance to Australia when they naturalised, which included a renunciation of other allegiances together with their long-term commitment to Australia.

It is fair to say that at the end of 1992 this did cause some major concerns for members of parliament. I was one of them. I do not recall the exact number, but there were certainly double figures of members of the House of Representatives and the Senate for whom there was an arguable case over whether they had failed to renounce the country of their home of birth. If there was a formal procedure, even if they had Australia citizenship, as a consequence of the High Court decision they were open to challenge—let us put it that way. I was one of those who, in a flurry of activity, dashed down to the British High Commission, sought out the details for renunciation of citizenship from Britain, paid the appropriate fee—which at that time was $50, I think—and lodged renunciation forms. There were quite a number of members of parliament at that time who had to go through that procedure.

In respect to myself, my father was an Australian who worked in England after the war. My mother was English. My father and my mother intended to come back to Australia in 1955. My father returned to Australia when my mother was pregnant with me. I had to stay in England until I was born apparently. You were not allowed to travel to Australia if a child was less than six months of age. I have to say, regrettably, that I was born in the United Kingdom. My kicking and screaming on the boat over here had nothing to do with my being sad about leaving the `motherland'. There were many members of this place who were in that position—not just, of course, through having been born in the United Kingdom but through having being born in other countries. I took out Australian citizenship in 1972 or 1973, having absolutely no idea that I, in any way, had some sort of legal connection with the English `motherland'.

It is a serious issue. As I said earlier, it has been raised in connection with Senator-elect Hill. Since Federation, a number of Australian acts of parliament have been passed that are relevant to determining when persons with dual Australian and British citizenship became ineligible under section 44(i), which I referred to earlier and which the High Court examined.

What is interesting is that at the time of Federation, and until the enactment of the Australian Citizenship Act in 1948, there was no such thing as an Australian citizen—Australians were British subjects, full stop. I do not intend to go into all of the legal detail but there have been a number of other acts of both the British and the Australian parliaments which are relevant to the issue of determining when a person with dual Australian and British citizenship became ineligible. They are such acts as the British Nationality Act 1948, Citizenship Act 1969, Australian Citizenship Act 1973, the Royal Style and Titles Act 1973, which uses the title `Queen of Australia', the 1981 British Nationality Act and the 1986 Australia Act. They are all relevant with respect to this issue of dual nationality.
One other point about the 1992 case Sykes v. Cleary was that that was about office of profit under the Crown. That was how the issue originally commenced, rather than on this dual citizenship matter.

I would like to turn now to the recent speculation concerning Senator-elect Heather Hill from Queensland. There are three aspects of this matter that have caused me particular concern. Firstly, prima facie—and I stress, prima facie—on the facts available as published in the media—and I think we have always got to be cautious about facts published in the media, particularly in this very intricate legal area—it does appear that Senator-elect Hill has a problem if she failed to renounce her British citizenship; if she failed to fill out the form, have it registered with the British High Commission and pay the fee.

Given all the publicity at the time of the High Court ruling in 1992, and that there has been subsequent publicity from time to time, we have to wonder how a political party such as One Nation which boasts of its professionalism—it is certainly professionally controlled and organised, some would say manipulated, by a ruling triumvirate—can be absolutely incompetent in the matter of dual citizenship. As I said, it is not as though it has been something that has been hidden; it has been a matter of extensive public debate. Certainly in the case of my party, and I am sure in the case of the Liberal Party and the National Party, all efforts are made to ensure that when people present for elections they are eligible under the constitution. But, of course, in respect of Senator-elect Hill, someone has to challenge her eligibility to sit in the Senate. It will be interesting to see where that challenge comes from.

What I thought was particularly offensive were some of the comments made by Senator-elect Hill. She has been publicly reported as alleging that her citizenship would not have been queried, `if I was Chinese or Vietnamese'. Of course, whether it relates to Chinese or Vietnamese or Greek or Italian or even, dare I say, Anglo-Saxon—people of Anglo-Celtic descent—is not the issue. The issue is whether or not she holds dual citizenship; that is the critical issue. I think it is very regrettable that Senator-elect Hill should attempt to off-load at least some of the responsibility for her possible error—and I say `possible' error—with a comment about Chinese or Vietnamese and to imply that that is an issue and an excuse. All that does, unfortunately, is feed off some of the racist sentiment that exists in sections of our community in Australia. I think that was an appalling remark for Senator-elect Hill to make.

It will be interesting to see if anyone in or associated with the National Party does take legal action. If they do, it will be no surprise that that will probably occur after next month's Mulgrave by-election in Queensland.

talk.start.para: —Why not the Labor Party?

—Senator Abetz says, `Why not the Labor Party?' I happen to have a view about what Senator-elect Hill can do and I would question, frankly, the practical value of such a challenge in respect of Senator-elect Hill.

speech.para: The third matter of concern that I have about this issue is, again, something that was reported in the media. It was in an article in the Age on 24 November. Apparently, according to this report, if you want to renounce British citizenship you now have to pay a fee of $800. It does fluctuate according to the exchange rate between the pound and the dollar. As I recall, when I renounced in late 1992 I think I paid $50 and collected the receipt. One of my Senate colleagues who renounced about 18 months to two years ago paid a fee of approximately $130. I was staggered to see it now costs $800 to renounce British citizenship.

It does seem extraordinary to me that, through accident of birth, those of us who were born in a particular country, in this case, the United Kingdom, but who are not particularly wanting any legal connection with the United Kingdom—no reflection on the United Kingdom—and who did not know that they had any legal connection with the United Kingdom are now faced with having to pay $A800 to be rid of a `privilege' they did not want and, in many cases, did not know they had. I certainly do not believe that an $800 fee is appropriate for the administrative costs, which are relatively minor. They must have imposed a surcharge when they upped the fee to $800.

They are the three aspects I raise. One is particularly serious, of course—the comment by Senator-elect Hill in respect of the Chinese or Vietnamese. I think that is very unfortunate, feeding on the racist sentiments in Australia. Secondly, I think she should have known if she had a problem—and we can only look at the facts as presented in the media, and I am always cautious about that.

Finally, I think it is an outrageously exorbitant fee that the British government is now charging to renounce citizenship, particularly in circumstances where people do not know of or do not want any particular legal association with the United Kingdom.

subdebateinfo.title: Drug Abuse and Drug Related Crime

talk.start.para: —I rise to speak on a matter that continues to be of significant public interest. Australian drug laws are in dire need of reform. There is no denying it. Most federal politicians have acknowledged this fact. But despite continued community pressure, this government has consistently failed to provide any new solutions to the problems stemming from drug abuse and drug related crime.

speech.para: The failure of the government's current Tough on Drugs approach was highlighted again at the First Annual Conference on Drugs and Young People in Melbourne. Conference delegates condemned the notion of zero tolerance, asserting that the emphasis of anti-drugs strategy should be placed on treatment rather than punishment. People working within the treatment field have been saying this for years but still the Howard government has continued to provide more punitive punishments for drug related crime. This government has consistently been more concerned with promoting an image of being tough on drugs than it has been with addressing the needs and concerns of the Australian people. This complete disregard and apathy for drug users and their families has led to a situation where even established treatment services are struggling to survive, with dwindling resources and funding. Not only has the government failed to introduce new treatment options for Australian drug users, it has failed in its duty of care to those participating in existing services.

It is the woeful inadequacy of counselling and other support services that I seek to highlight today. New pharmacotherapies have dominated recent debate in Australia about alternative treatment options for heroin users in particular. There is growing concern, however, among people from within the treatment field that the lack of support services provided for existing treatment options has contributed to low retention and high relapse rates among participants. Many treatment workers emphasise the need for ongoing support to be provided in order to address a user's psychological addiction and assist in social reintegration. Longer-term support services such as counselling and employment assistance help people to come to terms with the practicalities of life while they struggle to overcome their addiction. Such services provide a means of finding solutions to the problems that have often initiated drug abuse in the first place. Often drugs are used to escape the confines of reality. It is not enough to simply take the drugs away from people. We have to offer them some hope to replace them with. Counselling and employment services would be a good start. The provision of additional support services for participants in current treatment programs may therefore be a means of reducing relapse rates and enhancing the success of existing treatment strategies.

It has been suggested by some within the treatment field that outpatient services may provide a viable means of providing strong after-care support. The provision of outpatient services would make the range of treatment options already available more flexible and could conceivably be incorporated in any future treatment strategies involving new pharmacotherapies. The development of more flexible treatment services would enable easier access to therapy for many users, particularly those whose time is constrained by work or family commitments. It is often difficult for female users with young children to gain access to counselling services, particularly when they need to find child-care facilities at the same time.

The provision of additional support services, outpatient counselling services in particular, may be a means of improving the flexibility and long-term viability of existing treatment options. It would also represent a more practical and humane approach to dealing with Australia's burgeoning problem of drug use and drug related crime. We need to start looking at drug users as people. Until the government actually starts providing treatment options that address their needs in a more practical fashion, we cannot expect any improvements.

We need to look at why increasing amounts of Australians are turning to illicit drugs rather than dishing out arbitrary punishments. Many from within the treatment field recognise a growing need for specific counselling services to address underlying problems that are triggering drug use in many heroin users. It has been estimated that anywhere between 30 to 70 per cent of people in treatment for heroin dependence have unresolved issues of abuse, contributing to their psychological and physical addiction to heroin. Hence incorporating a wider range of counselling services within treatment programs could enhance the performance of existing treatment options.

The development and introduction of specific counselling services could improve the accessibility of treatment options for a significant number of Australian heroin users. Mr John Bynon, who recently helped to establish Australia's first program for abused male heroin users, is a strong advocate of such methods. He emphasises that it is often pointless to treat a person's drug addiction if that person initially turned to drugs to escape anguish resulting from other forms of abuse. Once again, we must seek to understand the problem before we can begin to address it.

The increasing incidence of drug use among young Australians is of particular concern to the community. The youth of today are this country's future and yet each year more and more of our young ones are lost to drugs. It is about time this government thought about developing some kind of proactive strategy to combat this trend rather than initiating further knee-jerk reactions in the arena of criminal law. Australians do not want to make their children criminals and outlaws; they want to offer them help. Many youth workers believe there is a rapidly growing need to establish more youth-specific heroin treatment options. With the incidence of heroin use amongst young people continuing to rise in Australia, there is an urgent need to provide new treatment options and support services relevant and appropriate for catering to their specific needs. Understandably enough, treatment facilities dealing with patients who—
(Time expired)

talk.start.para: —Order! The time for this discussion has concluded.

subdebateinfo.title: Goods and Services Tax: Banking Services

talk.start.para: —My question is addressed to Senator Kemp, the Assistant Treasurer. Does the Commonwealth Bank's $2 over the counter service fee fall within the category of services referred to by the Treas urer yesterday, that is, `fees for opening and keeping bank accounts, cheque accounts and the like', or does it fall within the category which you referred to on Monday of a `specific fee for service', in which case it would be subject to the full GST?
—Senator Conroy referred to a question that was answered fully and fulsomely by the Treasurer yesterday. The Treasurer put out a press statement on this issue, which I will table after question time.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Can the Assistant Treasurer explain precisely what he means by `specific fee for service'? Would EFTPOS fees fall within this category and therefore be slugged with a GST?

—Madam President, I do not think that is a supplementary question. Senator Conroy would be well advised to wait for the press release which I will be tabling after question time. That will make the issue absolutely crystal clear.

—Order! I draw the attention of honourable senators to the presence in the President's gallery of former Senator Michael Tate, a distinguished senator from Tasmania. I welcome you back to the national capital and hope that your visit here is very pleasant indeed.
—Hear, hear!

—My question is addressed to Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Hill. The government went to the last election with a comprehensive set of policies to strengthen the economy, to raise living standards, to look after families and to nurture small business. My question is: how important is it that these policies are implemented and what planning has been done to bring them about?

—I thank the honourable senator for his important question. He does raise the contrast between a government that has a clear plan, a comprehensive program and soundly based policies, and a Labor Party opposition that is devoid of ideas, devoid of intellectual contribution and has nothing at all to offer the Australian people. The program that we went to the people with at the last election, and which we seek to implement, builds upon our first term in office—a term during which we were able to offer the Australian people lower interest rates, low inflation, reduced unemployment, massive business investment and all the other benefits that can then flow from that to the betterment of all Australians.

answer.para: In our second term, we take to the Australian people a comprehensive taxation reform in order that Australian business can be as efficient as its competitors, continuing workplace reform in order to give young people in particular better job opportunities, a stronger health system with our reforms to support in particular the private health sector to build upon the record sums that we are investing in the public health sector in this country, a leadership role for APEC built on the substance of that strong domestic economy—

talk.start.para: —You sold us out of APEC. You know that!
—Order! Senator Cook, shouting in that fashion is totally out of order.

—Improvements in regional services, strong industry policies with an emphasis on information technology and information industries, a world-class education system, protection for the Australian environment through another $250 million contribution, assistance for families, an agenda for reconciliation and the referendum for the Australian people on a republic. This comprehensive plan was clearly put to the Australian people. It was supported by the community and is now to be implemented by this government.
