answer.para: What does the opposition offer instead? Obstructionism, no ideas, no policies, no nothing. What did Mr Beazley say? He rejected the so-called `new way'. He wanted a second way. That has now gone by the by. Mr Latham comes into the party room yesterday and says `It's not good enough,' so Mr Beazley says `It's time for intellectual input.' If this is the first sign that the Labor Party is prepared to recognise that one of the reasons it lost the last election was that it took to the Australian people no viable alternative, then it has taken a small step in the right direction. Now it needs three years to work up an alternative set of policies so that for once people of Australia will not be able to say that Labor stands for nothing. The time is now there for the Labor Party. They have another three years in opposition to think about what they stand for, to try to identify their place in the future of this country and to do the hard work that is necessary in relation to building policies. Then maybe, just maybe, they will come up with something worth while for the next election.

talk.start.para: —My question is directed to Senator Kemp, the Assistant Treasurer. Does the minister recall the Minister for Industry, Science and Resources saying yesterday in the Senate, `Under our new tax system Australian industry is going to save $10 billion a year in costs'? Is this true? Is the government no longer claiming that the reductions in costs that will flow to industry will be passed on to consumers? Is the government not double counting by claiming that that $10 billion in savings will go to industry and at the same time relying on those savings to justify its impossibly low inflation estimate of 1.9 per cent?

—If the minister referred to cost savings in the order of $10 billion for Australian industry, that is the correct figure as far as I am aware. But I will check that if you wish. All these costs are set out in some detail in an excellent book.
—Have you found the press release?

—Yes, I have found the press release, Senator Conroy, but I do not know what that has got to do with the question I am answering at the moment. One of the big features of our tax package which I think was of great appeal to Australian industry was the fact that we were able to take very substantial costs off industry. The GST is an extremely effective way of achieving that particular goal. Also, Senator Faulkner, there are very substantial cost savings in relation to exports.
—Wrong! Wrong!

—The exporters think it is. The exporters are very supportive of our tax reform package. Senator Cook is not supportive of our tax reform package, but the exporters are. In relation to this issue, Senator, I would prefer to support the exporters rather than you. They supported our tax package heaps, and they did not support your tax package.

answer.para: Senator Faulkner, you then referred to the inflationary impact of 1.9 per cent. I think that figure has been very carefully worked out and very carefully modelled. I do not think anything that the Labor Party has been able to produce has knocked the calculations on which that figure is based. I confirm that the package does show that there will be an inflationary rise of 1.9 per cent overall.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Can the Assistant Treasurer clarify how much of the much trumpeted $10 billion in savings from the new tax system the government expects will be pocketed by industry and how much, if any, will flow to consumers in lower prices?

—From memory, the questions that Senator Faulkner raised are in fact covered in the extensive tables in this book which I have referred to before. Again, Senator, I urge you to look through that book. It lists the cost savings by sector and it has other tables which deal with—
—You are kidding! Try answering the question.
—That is the answer to the question.

—My question is directed to Senator Ellison, the Minister representing the Minister for Education, Training and Youth Affairs. Will the minister advise the Senate of the coalition's strong commitment to giving young people the skills they need to compete in today's competitive work environment? In particular, will the minister advise the Senate how the Howard government's training policies have helped young Australians? Will the minister indicate the impact that alternative approaches could have on the number of young people in training?

—This is a very good question indeed from Senator Watson, because it touches on a very important issue for young Australians. What we are talking about here is training the next generation of young Australians to go forward and obtain jobs and carve out a future for themselves. I can say that, as the result of an agreement with the states and territories via the Australian National Training Authority agreement, some 55,000 extra places have now been provided through efficiencies.

answer.para: Senator Carr interjecting—

talk.start.para: —No doubt Senator Carr would be very interested in this indeed. It is predicted that these places will expand to 70,000 by the end of 1999. That only spells good news for young Australians.
—And no extra money from the government. No money from the government—someone else always has to pay.

—In relation to the funding, can I tell Senator Carr, Madam President, that this government is committed to $1.4 billion in the year 1998-99 in relation to vocational education and training. This is an increase of almost $200 million over Labor's last year. There is also funding of $295 million in relation to new apprenticeships. That will accommodate some 120,000 new apprenticeship positions. That is outstanding news for young Australians and also for older Australians who want to engage in training or upskilling.

answer.para: At the moment, there are over 190,000 people in training. That is a record for this country. Indeed, it is an indicator that this government is travelling in the right direction in relation to its policies on vocational education and training. Vocational education and training in Australian schools has been a subject close to my heart. We have provided $200 million over four years to expand vocational education and training opportuni ties in schools. Added to that, we have provided year 11 and 12 students with the opportunity to participate in vocational education courses.

What is significant is that in 1995 some 26,000 students were engaged in such courses but by 1998 that had increased dramatically to 114,000 students. What we have here is a recognition of those 70 per cent of students who do not go on to university; those 70 per cent of students who Labor neglected when it was in power.

We are looking at providing those 70 per cent of Australian students with an opportunity to do things other than go to university. This will provide new opportunities for them. Added to that, we are providing part-time training opportunities in courses which are accredited. Some 1,400 students across Australia have embarked upon this. This provides that those students can not only improve their literacy and numeracy skills, but they can also engage in an accredited course so that when they graduate from school there is a seamless transition from school to work and training, and they have somewhere to go when they leave. That is a lot more than was offered to young Australians in the past under the opposition when it was in government.

talk.start.para: —And they go to Centrelink, which isn't staffed any more.
—We have also got the Jobs Pathway program, which I am sure Senator Evans would be very interested in.
—Sit down!

—I hear the opposition say, `Sit down.' That is how much regard it has for the Jobs Pathway for young Australians. This is a very important subject, one which the opposition does not care about. We are worried about making sure that there are pathways for young Australians to go from school to work. From the interjections on the other side, it is obvious they do not give a hoot. They know they did nothing when they were in power and what we are providing is over $13 million. Some 83 projects have been funded to provide such pathways. (Time expired)

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, that is indeed an encouraging response, and congratulations on your part in that achievement. Could you give us further information in relation to this in particular and further indicate the impact the alternative approaches could have on the number of young people in training compared with the policy you have just enunciated?

—One can look at the alternative methods, especially those that I mentioned, which the opposition engaged in when it was in power, such as merry-go-round training programs which went nowhere and red tape—if you wanted to become an apprentice or trainee you could go to a multitude of government agencies and organisations and still be none the wiser.
—You told us the Job Network was wonderful.

—What we have introduced, Senator Campbell, is the new apprenticeship system and some 200 new apprenticeship sites which not only provide employers with information in relation to new apprenticeships but also, most importantly, provide it for those people who want to look into opportunities for themselves in relation to apprenticeships and traineeships. We have cut away the red tape. We have provided the opportunities for Australians to make inquiries and we have made it simple. We have increased the opportunity for employers to take on training. The International Monetary Fund has indicated that Australia is heading in the right direction in building more opportunities for training and jobs. (Time expired)

subdebateinfo.title: Goods and Services Tax: Fringe Benefits

talk.start.para: —My question is directed to the Assistant Treasurer. What will be the FBT impact under the GST regime for an employer who pays, or reimburses employees, for GST-free activities such as health, education or child care?
—I will take that question on notice, look at the detail and provide you with an answer.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I was hoping it would follow from the answer to the first one. Will there be a different FBT impact under the GST regime for an employer who reimburses employees—
—Order! It is important that people are able to hear what is being said in the chamber.

—Madam President, I take a point of order. Senator Crossin is obviously starting a second question. It is not something that has arisen out of the answer to the first question. It is therefore not a supplementary question in terms of the standing orders and she should not be permitted to ask it.
—Then make your minister answer the question.
—Senator Conroy! Cease behaving like that.
—On the point of order, Madam President, we have a situation where we have an incredibly incompetent minister in Senator Kemp—
—That is not a point of order.
—I am speaking to the point of order. He has only two methods of answering a question, either waffling or saying he will take the question on notice.
—That is not speaking to the point of order.

—My point on the point of order taken by Senator Hill is that, given that the minister has indicated that he intends to take the question on notice, surely it is proper for Senator Crossin in a supplementary question to be able to outline further details of what she requires from this minister who is totally incapable of answering any question in this chamber.

—On the point of order, Madam President, I refer you to a statement that was made by someone who some people would say is a very distinguished parliamentarian—others would have a different view—Mr Keating, when asked to provide somewhat technical advice on tax matters. This is what he said:

question.para: If the honourable member wants a technical explanation of the differences—
referring to a technical taxation question—
Question Time is not the time or the place to give it.
That is a principle which I think is a most appropriate one, and I intend to follow it.

talk.start.para: —Senator Kemp, that is not relevant to the current point of order. The question we are dealing with is whether or not Senator Crossin's supplementary question is supplementary. It could not be supplementary to the answer, but the status of such questions has been considered previously by the Procedure Committee and it has become the practice that questions can be supplementary to the question. The first words she uttered—which were all I heard—indicated that it was at least the same topic as previously. I would need to hear the whole of the question to know whether it was supplementary to the question.
—In other words, you can't protect him.
—Senator Faulkner, it is out of order to behave in that fashion.

—Will there be a different FBT impact under the GST regime for an employer who reimburses employees for a GST input-taxed activity, such as an employee who pays, or receives reimbursement for the payment of, private rent?
—Not to question your ruling, of course, Madam President, but I would respectfully put to you that that is a supplementary question arising out of her question and not out of the answer—
—That is correct.
—And a supplementary question must arise out of the answer, not out of the original or primary question.

—Supplementary questions initially, when they were introduced to the Senate, had to be supplementary to the answer. In recent years, most supplementary questions have been supplementary to the original question and not the answer. When the Senate referred that matter to the Procedure Committee, as I said a few minutes ago, it was the view of the Procedure Committee that the way things were functioning at the present time was the way it would continue. If Senator Kemp has anything he wishes to add, he may do so.
—Yes, I do have some information which I wish to add. If that is a serious question and you want a direct response to it, I will certainly supply that to you when I am improperly informed.

—Madam President, my question is directed to the Minister for the Environment and Heritage. I refer to this week's conference of more than 250 world experts in coral reef science in Townsville. Minister, is it true that your government specifically instructed the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority not to link the worldwide and disastrous coral bleaching to global warming, in spite of overwhelming evidence to the contrary? Are you aware that international scientists and reef managers are angry and that they are accusing your government of scientific censorship?

—That is news to me. Can I firstly say that I hope the honourable senator has had an opportunity to peruse the State of the Great Barrier Reef world heritage area 1998 report that was released yesterday. It is principally the result of about three years of scientific assessment and records the good state the assets are in, which is a credit to the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority's management and supervision of the reef and something of which all Australians would obviously be proud.

answer.para: In relation to the coral bleaching that has occurred in the last 12 months—which does occur from time to time—yes, this latest occurrence early this year was more severe than is usually the case. On this occasion it is believed to have been related to an increase in water temperature in the relevant areas. There is some suggestion that there may have been other factors involved, including turbidity and some other stressful occurrences. Having said that, there is still no compelling evidence that the particular instance of warmer water this year is related to climate change activities associated with greenhouse gases. The bottom line is that scientists do not know why this occurs from time to time and the issue will continue to remain one for debate and research. Hopefully in the future we might better understand these occurrences, and if it is possible—although the chances are that it will not be—that some human action can be taken to deter the increase in temperature, that might take place.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the minister for his answer, but again I ask: Minister, did you or your officials try to suppress in any way the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority's concern about that link between coral bleaching and global warming? I think you did not quite answer that question, so I put it to you again. Why did the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority call a press conference to say that coral bleaching was related to the wet season when at the same time world experts were saying that the biggest threat to coral reefs was rising sea temperatures linked to global warming?

—I just said that there is a concern that run-off could be contributing to this factor. I also said that it is not known yet whether there is any link between these occurrences of increased temperature in the water and emissions of greenhouse gases. Lastly, GBRMPA's brief to me was as I just related to the honourable senator—that is, that there is no established link. That is the view of the authority.

subdebateinfo.title: Goods and Services Tax: Input Credits

talk.start.para: —My question is to Senator Kemp, the Assistant Treasurer. In regard to the remitting of GST input credits to registered businesses, will a business lose its input credit when an item it has purchased is used less than 50 per cent for business purposes?
—I suggest that that particular question wait until the bill is tabled in the House of Representatives. We will provide an answer then.

—My question is to the Minister for the Environment and Heritage representing the Minister for Forestry and Conservation. I refer the minister to the WA Legislative Council Standing Committee on Ecologically Sustainable Development report on its inquiry into the WA Regional Forest Agreement which recommended, amongst other things, that the WA Department of Conservation and Land Management be replaced as lead agency for the RFA, that the RFA be finalised through an accord process and that the draft RFA be released for public comment and assessment by the EPA. I ask: given that this unanimous report of the all-party standing committee reflects a broad concern in the community about the direction of the WA RFA, what is the current WA RFA, when is it expected to be signed and will the Commonwealth government be implementing any of the recommendations in the Legislative Council's standing committee report?

—I suppose I should start by congratulating Mr Tuckey on his appointment as Minister for Forestry and Conservation. Mr Tuckey will of course bring to the Western Australian Regional Forest Agreement local knowledge as well as years of practical and useful experience in relation to natural resource matters. Having said that, the progress on an RFA for Western Australia, whilst it is a little slower than I would have liked, remains on track. It is true that the Western Australian Legislative Council conducted an inquiry and came to the conclusion that what was needed in Western Australia was a negotiated outcome between all stakeholders—the sort of solution that one would have suggested could only come from a `green' chairman of the committee. It is totally unworkable, nevertheless that is the way it is. The report was of course to the Western Australian Legislative Council, and how the Western Australian parliament responds to it is something to be determined by the Western Australian parliament.

answer.para: In relation to the RFA, as the honourable senator would know, the reports on options have now been out for some time. There was a period for contribution from interested parties, an opportunity to make submissions. In fact over 30,000 public submissions were received. They have been analysed, which was a huge task in itself. We have even had an independent audit done on the process of receipt and analysis of submissions so there can be no suggestion that they will not be properly taken into account. The negotiation between the Commonwealth government and the Western Australian government continues and is now well advanced. I am hopeful that it will reach a conclusion in the reasonably near future.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. The minister failed to answer the specific question in relation to the environmental impact assessment. Given that the Western Australian RFA scoping agreement states that the draft RFA will be released for EPA assessment, will the minister ensure that this commitment is met? If he does not, do the agreements between states and the federal government mean anything at all?

—Under Western Australian legislation the agreement must go to the WA EPA, which is somewhat different from other states when the local assessments become part of the RFA negotiation itself. Obviously if that is the requirement of Western Australian law, that will be complied with.

subdebateinfo.title: Goods and Services Tax: Voluntary School Fees

talk.start.para: —My question without notice is to Senator Kemp, the Assistant Treasurer. Will the GST be applicable to various voluntary user fees charged by government schools as opposed to tuition fees for private schools which will be GST-free?
—Some of these issues were considered in the Vos committee report.
—Can we have a look?

—Yes, you can. When the report is tabled by the Treasurer, you will be able to have a look. That issue and the issue of which areas are GST-free are considered in that report. That will enable me to provide a detailed response to your question. This package is one which is very beneficial to education. Make no mistake, the education sector is a very big winner in the tax reform package that the government has brought down. We will make sure that wherever practical the fees in relation to private schools and public schools are treated in an equitable and fair manner.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Given that answer, Minister, how does the government justify to the parents of students at Broadmeadows Secondary College that they should be subsidising the fees paid by parents who can afford to send their children to Geelong Grammar? Will the government ensure that parents of students at government schools will not have to pay a GST on so-called voluntary fees, which in effect they have no choice but to pay?

—Fees which are paid in relation to education are GST-free. I am not sure what point you are making. I was under the impression you were making another point. I was thinking of making another point: those fees which were not compulsory in relation to curriculum.
—You were talking about the Vos committee. You can't have it both ways.

—Senator Faulkner, if you could just keep quiet for the briefest of moments one could respond to the question. Fees in relation to educational activities are GST-free. That applies to private and public schools. I thought you were speaking about various fees in relation to clubs and societies—in that voluntary sense.

—My question without notice is to the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts, Senator Alston. I note today information about Online Australia Day this Friday, 27 November. Will the Minister explain to the Senate the importance of this day and the activities to be staged around Australia?

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: —Online Australia Day is this coming Friday. It is a very important opportunity to ensure that there is maximum awareness in the general public of the tre mendous practical value that derives from online services, electronic commerce and a whole raft of new technologies. It is well-known not only that Australians are notoriously early adopters of new technologies but also that when it comes to PCs, for example, we are not far behind the US in household penetration, which runs at about one-third. About 14 per cent of households are connected to the Internet and use the Internet regularly—well ahead of other countries.
—What are the stats for rural Australia?

—The stats for rural Australia are that you failed comprehensively to deliver the goods. You made a complete goose of yourself at Albury. The industry is amazed that you even got a guernsey as shadow minister shadowing the shadow minister. Apart from that we have performed brilliantly.
—Senator Alston, you should be addressing your remarks through the chair.

—I am sorry, Madam President. I was provoked. We certainly accept an obligation to ensure that all Australians are aware of not only the Internet and those facilities but also the enormous job opportunities that are provided and the emerging global skills shortage that will mean that many school graduates will be able to get very significant premiums from pursuing computer related careers. We do have an obligation to ensure that people have access to maximum benefits to ensure that those who are otherwise missing out in rural and remote Australia are given all the opportunities that the Labor Party would simply deny them. We funded them through a $250 million regional telecommunications infrastructure fund which the Labor Party opposed tooth and nail during the original Telstra debate and then put out a press release during the election campaign—in the name of Senator Schacht but obviously endorsed by the rest of the crew—basically knocking off the money. It was pure political theft. You will not be forgotten for that.

answer.para: The Internet does offer tremendous opportunities. It breaks down the tyranny of distance. It enables much greater levels of social interaction in rural areas. It enables people to tackle new markets not only in Australia but around the world. It provides access to a plethora of information for both adults and schoolchildren. It provides enormous opportunities for online commerce, both business to business and business to consumers. In many respects IT and the information economy are going to drive us into the next millennium.

Online Australia Day is part of a concerted effort by this government. We have proclaimed 1999 Online Australia Year. We held Australia's first electronic summit, e-commerce summit, in April this year designed to energise business into taking up the commercial opportunities. Over the last six months the national Office for the Information Economy has been conducting a series of regional summits. We are going to have 30 in all to ensure that people do understand these benefits.

This Online Australia Day will involve not only the launch of a federal government web site for families but a virtual classroom linking 40 schools around Australia, Internet access and classes in more than 700 schools and libraries, the launch of the Farmwide satellite based trial and online ABC forums—in other words, a whole raft of opportunities. People will even be able to see whether Senator Schacht has managed to update his web site in the last 18 months. I am sure they will not bother going to Senator Lundy's because she is still learning the technology. No doubt the Labor Party is offered the resources to try and assist those who have some degree of computer literacy. Online Australia Day should be a unique opportunity. I am sure the unions will fund the purchase of technology for you and there will be free laptops all round. (Time expired)

subdebateinfo.title: Goods and Services Tax: Impact on Consumer Price Index

talk.start.para: —My question is to the Assistant Treasurer, Senator Kemp. I refer to the recent changes made to the CPI's measurement methodology and in particular the inclusion for the first time of expenditure on dwellings. Minister, given that $17.2 billion was spent on residential building in 1997-98, what will be the impact on the CPI as a result of the GST induced price increases for housing costs? How does this change impact on the government's economy-wide estimate that prices will rise by only 1.9 per cent under the GST?

—As Senator Cook said, the estimate is that prices will rise by 1.9 per cent overall as a result of the tax reform program. A wide range of taxes are coming off and there is the imposition of a GST. The overall effect on the economy has been estimated, as a result of Treasury modelling, at 1.9 per cent. This takes into account all the data which is available to the Treasury. We believe—and the Labor Party has not been able to shake these statistics one iota, I might say—that the overall effect will be 1.9 per cent.

answer.para: During the last week of the election campaign, the Labor Party ran some very extensive advertisements which argued that the impact of the GST would be five times the figure which had been estimated by the government. That was wrong; that was a lie. We have not had one apology from the Labor Party for those quite disgraceful ads. We believe that the figures which have been produced which show the overall impact of the GST are fair.

talk.start.para: —That's not true.

—They have been modelled by the Treasury on the best data available to them. The Labor Party, despite great efforts on their part to shake this figure, have not been able to do so, and we stand by that 1.9 per cent figure.
—That's not true and you know it.
—Senator Conroy, you have been interjecting far too frequently.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I am tempted to give the minister another minute to further humiliate himself by adding to his answer, because he did not answer the question that I put. The question I put was about the change in the measurement methodology of the consumer price index and the impact that will have on the CPI. You did not answer that question, Minister.

—Madam President, I raise a point of order. Senator Cook has been going on for almost the entire minute and has not yet formed anything in the shape of a question. I therefore ask you to rule him out of order because he is simply not asking a question.

—On the point of order, Madam President: it is normal practice to allow a questioner in the Senate to complete their question before you make a judgment whether there is a question involved. If Senator Alston could wait that long instead of desperately trying to protect Senator Kemp, who cannot answer any questions at all, I am sure he will find that there will be a question—and another one that Senator Kemp cannot answer.
—There was a long introduction, but it was my impression that you were asking a question. Please do so, Senator Cook.

—Thank you, Madam President. Minister, given that interest rate related changes will drop out of the headline CPI, will Treasury target, firstly, the new CPI headline rate or, secondly, Treasury's measure of underlying inflation rate, in its consideration of monetary policy settings?

—From the point of view of humiliation, Senator Cook, there was no greater humiliation than occurred on 12 November 1997 in a Senate legislation committee. That humiliation was arguably the greatest political meltdown since Federation.
—What did he do?

—I will not tell you what he did because I may well table that after question time, or I may not table that, in case you do not know what the case is, Senator. We have a new index, the 13th series, and that is the index which will be very widely used.

—My question is also to the Assistant Treasurer. I refer to the Prime Minister's comments last night that there can be no mergers among the four big banks until competition improves. I ask the minister to advise the Senate as to what exactly the Prime Minister means when he says:

question.para: I don't see the conditions of greater competition as having yet been satisfied in order to meet the [sort of] criteria we had in mind when we enunciated our response to the Wallis inquiry.

Could the minister outline to the Senate the detailed criteria that the government believes are necessary for a competitive banking system? Is one of the criteria correcting the market power of the banks to impose whatever fees they want on their customers? Is another the introduction of the basic banking accounts promised four years ago so that pensioners and social security recipients are not slugged with fees?

talk.start.para: —In relation to the second part of the question, a variety of banks now offer accounts called transactions accounts.
—Is that one of your criteria?

—You asked me the second part of the question about what pensioners and others can make use of. In relation to the first part of the question, what we are looking at is effectively giving consumers more power.
—I'm not sure the Commonwealth bank customers can take much more power!
—Order! There are far too many interjections on my left and I would ask that Senator Kemp be heard in the chamber.

—In other words, the banking sector will have to be far more responsive to consumers. What we are seeking in relation to the financial sector is to enable the consumer to have widespread choice and for there to be effective competition between the banks, which will drive down costs and ultimately deliver benefits to the consumer in terms of cheaper services. We have travelled some way along that road. I do not think there is any doubt that, as a result of the reforms that we have brought in, we have been able to increase competition in the financial sector. Therefore, in a variety of banking areas we can point to some very real successes. One of those successes, of course, is the really historically low interest rates which are now available. But we still say there is a way to go.
—You've still got a way to go.
—Order! There are still far too many interjections all around the chamber. Senators should observe the standing orders.

—Our policies are designed to increase competition. We believe competition has increased but, nonetheless, there is certainly a way to go. The ultimate end of a competitive market is to provide cheaper and effective services to consumers and to provide consumers with a range of choices. That is why this government is determined, as distinct from previous governments, to make sure that we have a truly competitive financial sector.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, is it not the case that the government's policies are in effect giving more power to the banks, not more powers to consumers as you claim? Yesterday the other Assistant Treasurer, Joe Hockey, engaged in a spirited defence of banks, suggesting that people who complained about increased fees were actually subsidising an old banking system. As the Treasurer's right-hand man, does the minister endorse the comments of the Treasurer's left-hand man who, according to the Treasury web site, still has no specific job duties? Does this mean that Australians now face the prospect not of a government that prevents banks from increasing fees but a government that is encouraging banks to do so?
—Senator, if I can take the last part of your question, you have got this truly wrong.
—I have it here.

—We are about providing market forces which enable better services to consumers. As I said, in a number of areas we can point to some important gains. We are very keen to bring about effective competition in the marketplace for financial services so that consumers have real choices. I have not had the opportunity to closely read what Mr Joe Hockey has said. Frankly, I am always loath to accept quotations which may have been taken out of context. However, on your recommendation I shall read closely what Mr Hockey said yesterday.

—My question is directed to the Assistant Treasurer, Senator Kemp. Does the minister regard as valid the criticism by business groups of the timing of its proposals to include fringe benefits on employee group certificates? Will the government be giving consideration to delaying these changes until April 2000? I also ask what credence the minister gives to claims that the proposed changes have the potential:

question.para: . . . to render the Fringe Benefits tax and related rules the most complex that exist, both from a technical and an administrative point of view.

Will the government be meeting with the Law Council of Australia, the Institute of Chartered Accountants, the Taxation Institute of Australia, the Australian Society of CPAs and the Australian Taxpayers Association to discuss this matter?

talk.start.para: —I would like to make a couple of points. Firstly, Senator, you have actually asked me to explain your policy. Did whoever passed you that question tell you that that was actually the policy that you took to the election? Did they say that to you? This is unique. If I am wrong I am sure senators will correct me, and you have a supplementary and a good chance to correct me. I am looking at Senator Cook, who helped write this very unsuccessful tax policy. He can nod or shake his head to indicate whether my memory does serve me. My memory was that the Labor Party picked up all the fringe benefits tax changes which the government proposed in its election policy. So this is a unique case in that a Labor Party senator has got to his feet and asked me to explain Labor Party policy—very unusual. The other comment that I would make is that I think the Labor Party picked up this policy—
—Option C! Option C!
—Order! Shouting across the chamber is unacceptable behaviour.

—The other comment that I would make is that the Labor Party picked up this policy because they, like us, saw there was a need to make sure there was a significant improvement in the fringe benefits area. We moved down that road in relation to our tax reform package and you, in this section, moved exactly down the same road. Unlike you, we always listen carefully to a wide range of groups—community groups and business groups. If they wish to put forward views to us, we will always listen to those views. In the implementation of the tax package, Senator, we will certainly ensure that it is done in a way which minimises problems for the business community. That is, of course, part of the ongoing consultations that—
—Will you answer the question?

—I have answered the question. The policy that is stated in our tax reform program is that the reporting of grossed up taxable value of fringe benefits greater than $1,000 on group certificates will be from the 1999-2000 year. Senator, I am not aware of any moves to have that changed at this time.

—Just for the record, I should answer your kind invitation, Minister. It is not the position of our party to support the GST. We will not support it in the future and we will oppose it when it comes. In the context of the answer to the specific question, we thank you for advising that you will not extend the implementation date until April 2000.

question.para: I ask a supplementary question, Madam President. Minister, in regard to the use of group certificates for the collection of FBT, do you recall saying on 6 May 1997 that the use of group certificates for collection of the superannuation surcharge tax would `involve some one million employers, would involve some 10 million taxpayers with their group certificates' and that, in rejecting the group certificate method for collecting the surcharge tax, you said you `were not prepared to impose additional red tape on small business in particular'? Minister, what has changed your mind on the use of group certificates for the collection of FBT?

talk.start.para: —Senator Bishop did not clarify his question. His question was not about the GST, which we know the Labor Party does not support; it was about the FBT, which we understood the Labor Party did support. It was actually in their policy, so the clarification he gave us was not effective. What has changed is that we have a major tax reform package which is designed, among other things, to assist business.
—Biggest burden of red tape ever given.
—Order! Senator Conroy, stop interjecting.

—In a number of important areas—the withholding of a range of payments—there will be substantial savings to business. There have been statistics indicating that some companies have up to 32 contacts with the tax office each year. Under our proposals, these contacts with the tax office can be reduced to, from memory, about four. We believe that the overall picture is that business will certainly benefit substantially. (Time expired)
—My question is addressed to the Minister for Regional Services, Territories and Local Government, Senator Ian Macdonald.
—Oh!
—Order! That sort of reaction is absolutely not helpful and it is quite absurd.

—Minister, rural communities will be big winners under the government's tax reform plan. Will you inform the Senate what will be the effect of taxation reform on rural communities? Will you outline the huge reductions in transport costs and freight charges in country areas? What will be the effect of the introduction of a GST, particularly on local government?

talker.name: Macdonald, Sen Ian
Senator IAN MACDONALD
talker.role: Regional Services, Territories and Local Government

talk.start.para: —Madam President, Senator Ferguson will know, because he comes from regional Australia, that it is one of the most important parts of Australia when it comes to export earnings and the wealth that this nation creates. Senator Ferguson, because he comes from the country and because he has interests in the country, will know that the best thing you can do for business in rural and regional Australia is to get interest rates down, get inflation down and look at unemployment problems and attend to them. I am very pleased to say that in the first term of the Howard government we did that.
—What about regional banking?
—Order! Senator Conroy, you have been interjecting throughout.

—We hope to have the opportunity of initiating our tax reform package, and I hope the Democrats will help us in this because it is just so important for rural and regional Australia. Senator Ferguson asked me what the impacts will be. Regional businesses will share in the $10 billion reduction in costs to Australian business if we are able to implement our reform package.
—On a point of order, Madam President: can the rural members having a subcommittee be seated so they can hear this very important answer on rural matters?
—Order! I call Senator Macdonald.

—It would be more important, Madam President, if Senator Ray would listen to this because he and his colleagues have absolutely no interest in rural and regional Australia, despite the fact that most of the wealth of our nation comes from there.

answer.para: There will be, with the tax reform package, reductions of up to $1.1 billion in the cost to agricultural industries. In the export area, costs will fall by $4.5 billion. They are huge savings for rural and regional Australia. They will in fact give rural Australia the sort of boost that it did not see in the 13 years prior to the Howard government taking office.

As well, we have done quite a lot of other things in rural and regional Australia which we will build upon. You will all remember the $525 million agricultural Advance Australia package, the $1.25 billion Natural Heritage Trust—much of which went to rural and regional Australia—the Federation Fund, and a lot of good work done on the highways.

Senator Ferguson asked me what will come out of the new tax reform package more specifically for the bush. Once you address interest rates, once you address inflation, once you help reduce unemployment in rural and regional areas, the best thing you can possibly do is get the costs of transport down. That is what the tax reform package will do.

We will be reducing the costs of the big trucks that take goods out into rural and regional Australia and take goods from rural and regional Australia back to the ports by 22 per cent because the wholesale sales tax will go completely. It will be replaced by a 10 per cent GST but, because it is an input into business, it will go completely. So the cost of those huge trucks will fall by 22 per cent, and that will make the cost of transport to rural and regional Australia so much better. In addition to that, those trucks that run out to rural and regional Australia and bring the goods back into port—
Opposition senators interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Order! The level of noise on my left is absolutely unacceptable.

—Madam President, they have absolutely no interest in rural and regional Australia. In fact, they appointed as their spokesman someone who, when she moved from the Gold Coast to the outskirts of Brisbane, thought she was moving to the bush; someone who quite clearly told her former colleagues in the Democrats not to go near the bush because there were no votes there at all. That is the sort of insult the Labor Party put out to people in rural and regional Australia.

answer.para: As I was saying, the cost of running those trucks out into rural and regional Australia and of bringing the goods back into ports are quite enormous.(Time expired)
Opposition senators interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Order! Behaviour in the chamber is absolutely unacceptable and disgraceful. It brings the chamber into disrepute. The level of noise is absolutely unacceptable.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I ask the Minister to further inform us of the effect of tax reform, of the GST, particularly on local government, which was the last part of my question.

talker.name: Macdonald, Sen Ian
Senator IAN MACDONALD
talker.role: Regional Services, Territories and Local Government

talk.start.para: —Thank you, Senator Ferguson. I had not quite got around to explaining the benefits regarding transport costs. Fuel will fall by 25c a litre for the big trucks that bring the goods from rural and regional areas into the ports.

answer.para: In relation to local government, there is more good news. Local government rates and charges and all regulatory matters will be absolutely GST free. They will get rid of all the wholesale sales tax inputs, the indirect ones that really account for some $70 million on local government in Australia. And, in fact, they will make huge savings from the cut in fuel costs. For example, the Queensland Local Government Association—(Time expired)

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper .

—Yesterday, Senator Lundy asked me a question relating to an investigation of millennium bug documents. I can advise that an investigation is being conducted and, in accordance with the longstanding practice of successive governments, I have nothing further to add to that. It was referred directly by DoFA to the Australian Federal Police.

subdebateinfo.title: Knowles, Senator Sue: Alleged Death Threats

talk.start.para: —Senator Cook asked a question—quite inappropriately, in my view, but nonetheless tagged it slightly to my responsibility—as to whether the AFP had used any resources in relation to Senator Knowles. I am advised the answer is no.

subdebateinfo.title: Goods and Services Tax: Banking Services

talk.start.para: —As indicated in question time, I table the press release which was discussed in the question by Senator Conroy. I do not propose to table the extract from Hansard of 12 November 1997 which involved Senator Cook.
—I move:

speech.para: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Assistant Treasurer (Senator Kemp), to a question without notice asked by Senator Conroy today, relating to the proposed goods and services tax and bank fees.

What we have seen today has been one of the most pitiful attempts to answer the questions that have been put before him. There have been 16 questions in three days—16 questions he has had from the opposition—but he has not answered one. That is what we have seen. `It is in the book', he says, `it is in the press release.' It is anywhere but in his head! We have a situation at the moment—and I am glad you have come back, Senator Kemp—

talk.start.para: —But I am not staying for you; don't get your hopes up.

—where banks in this country are making massive profits, and this government wants to duck facing up to it. We are seeing exorbitant, excessive profiteering and greed from the banks. We are seeing a 20 per cent return on shareholders' capital on retail banking—and that is on ordinary mums and dads and pensioners and battlers. There is a 20 per cent return coming to the banks. That is what is happening out there right now. We are seeing massive increases in fees and charges.

speech.para: And what did Mr Hockey, the minister, say? He said that they have a system:
where we have the opportunity to get the full benefit of user pays.
That is in yesterday's Hansard . That is where this government is coming from—`the full benefit of user pays'.

The banks have not stopped yet. Everybody in the industry knows there are more fees and increased charges coming. Everybody in the community knows they are coming. What is this government trying to do? They are trying to claim all the credit for interest rates being low but, when banks lose their margins and recoup it through fees and charges, what do they say? They say, `It is nothing to do with us. We are responsible for the low interest rates but, just because the banks are making their money in a different way from ordinary punters, that is nothing to do with us. There is nothing we can do about it.' They claim the credit on the one hand, but they do not want to face up to what is happening to ordinary battlers out there in Australia.

Yesterday Mr Hockey said, `There is a simple choice. Do you want lower interest rates or do you want competition in the provision of financial services?' I always thought competition was supposed to be about seeing fees and charges going down—not going up, because that is what is happening. In the last decade, a decade that had low inflation and modest economic growth, we have seen bank profits for the big four increase by 440 per cent. Bank profits are up by 440 per cent. The profits of the big four have grown 3½ times faster than the economy as a whole. In 1997, the big four earned $3.2 billion more from fees and charges than at the start of the decade. We have seen massive increases.

talk.start.para: —What did you do in 13 years?

—Senator McGauran asks, `What did you lot do? What did you do when you were in government?' The fees and charges have come because the margins have been squeezed from interest rates being low. But you claim you are not responsible for it. The real push for fees and charges has come in the last couple of years and you try to pretend it has nothing to do with you; you do not have to take any responsibility for it. Senator McGauran, as bank branches have closed in rural Victoria, you have said abso lutely nothing. You have been silent. As ordinary battlers out there in Gippsland have had fees and charges stuck on top of them day after day and massive increases, what have you said? Absolutely nothing.

—I rise on a point of order. Madam Deputy President, I draw your attention to the standing orders. Is Senator Conroy going to be forced to address his remarks through the chair or is he just going to scream at another senator across the chamber?
—No, he is going to be asked to address the chair. Some of the interjections can cease too. Senator Conroy, please speak to the chair.

—What we have seen is silence from this government. As bank branches in suburbs of major cities have been hitting the fence, where have the government been? Running away from it. They do not want to face up to it. But there is a community obligation involved. Even Don Argus admits there is a community obligation involved in banking.
—He is retiring.

—Exactly, Senator Forshaw. Now he is retiring he has a bit of courage. That is what he has had to say on the issue. Even the National Bank, Australia's biggest bank, has turned round and said, `There is a community service obligation.' What has this government done? It is ignoring it: it wants it to go away. According to the minister, Mr Hockey, you have a choice: you get higher interest rates or fees and charges. Those are the choices faced by the community. The government does not want to face up to it.
—Twenty-one per cent interest rates.
—As bank branches have closed in Tasmania, Senator Calvert has said nothing. (Time expired)

—I find today's debate, yet again, quite bewildering. The Labor Party, very carefully and selectively, forget their record. Let us not forget that the very state that the previous speaker, Senator Conroy, comes from is the state that had a Labor government that saw banks go into huge decline, branches close one after the other and the State Bank hit the wall. I note that Senator Conroy is walking straight out of the chamber. He does not want to listen. He is too embarrassed. The fact of the matter is that it was the Labor state government that made sure that people's money was put at risk and they are the ones that made sure that branches closed everywhere.
—And in South Australia.

—And in South Australia, and in Western Australia, my own state. As if the Western Australian Labor government did not do enough through the WA Inc. years to ensure insecurity through building societies and credit unions. Let us not forget also that the Labor Party was in government for 13 years federally and during that time it could have chosen to do what the coalition government has already done in but a few short years and will come into action next month, and that is, allow the building societies and credit unions to issue cheques in their own names, thereby increasing competition and giving greater flexibility to those people who choose to use building societies and credit unions as their alternative source of savings and financial communication.

speech.para: Let us also not forget that, under the Liberal and National coalition government, the average family is now $300 a week better off than it would have been under the Labor government. But that is also forgotten. Those opposite say, `Let us just make sure that we forget all of the things that have been done and simply look at some manufactured answer.' We sit in this chamber every solitary day and hear the distortions about what the tax reform policy is going to do. We hear about simply adding on a 10 per cent tax.

Those opposite know that that is not true, but they keep repeating it. Equally, the ones who want to be a little more honest say that it will simply remove the wholesale sales tax and put on a 10 per cent tax. But they do not talk about all the taxes coming off. They do not talk about how many taxes there are. Let us not forget that there are many taxes. Here we are with Labor, nearly three years into opposition, having been defeated the second time, still pretending that the system they created and loyally defended is working. They are pretending that it helps businesses when it actually hurts businesses and hurts job creation. They should know that, because they were the ones that had a million people unemployed. They were the ones that had interest rates at 17 per cent.

talk.start.para: —21 per cent.

—Or 21 per cent. Thank you, Senator Calvert. They know how many businesses went broke during their time of government, and they know how income tax rates were crushing families year after year. We want to fix this 1930s tax system—which they wanted to do 13 years ago, and still have not had the courage to do purely and simply because they thought they could win an election on it. It is an old, outdated system. The new tax system will have one simple tax. Why not start to be honest about what the tax proposals are all about and not divert off to these side issues when they actually created the problem? It is this government trying to fix it.

speech.para: The lights having gone out in the chamber—

talk.start.para: —We don't seem to be able to fix much with the electricity system! But this approach is just so symptomatic of what they are doing. But also let us remind you that the new tax system is going to abolish the financial institutions duty, which is the money that you are charged when you put your money into the account. It will abolish the bank account debits tax, the money you are charged when you take money out of your bank account. It will abolish stamp duty on mortgages when people buy homes. It will abolish stamp duties on shares, and it will abolish stamp duties on leases. It will abolish stamp duties and bed taxes. (Time expired)

—Such was the power of that last speech it plunged most of us into the dark! We might as well stay with that because what we have is a government that refuses to take on the banks, a government that claims that it is here on behalf of the citizens but has refused to take on the banks. The opening paragraph of an article by AAP in the Canberra Times today, Wednesday, 25 November, says that the federal government refused yesterday to even criticise the Commonwealth Bank's pre-Christmas decision to raise fees and charges, instead advising customers to shop around. I think it says it in a nutshell.

speech.para: We can add to that the failure of this government to take any responsibility for these fees and the answers given in this Senate today by Minister Kemp, which are a pathetic attempt to obfuscate at every turn. They do not want to answer. They do not want to deal with it. They do not want to deal with the fact that these charges have gone up.

Senator Knowles has just made some virtue of the fact that the GST will do away with some of those bank charges. Well, why aren't you complaining bitterly about the one that the bank is putting on? On the one hand, you are taking some of those charges away; with the other hand, they are slipping another one on. And who are going to be affected? It will be the people who use their accounts most, including the little people with small accounts—people like pensioners, school children and small savers who do not want to be carrying a large amount of cash around, who therefore go often to the bank to draw their money from the tellers, and who might often, if they are actually up to it, want to be bothered using an automatic teller machine. These are the people who are going to be hit by these charges—not the top end of town, who will be enormously advantaged by your government's proposals in health and in tax and all sorts of different systems. You do not give a hoot for the people at the bottom end of town, and you do not care at all about what banks are doing.

talk.start.para: —Oh! What about a million unemployed under Labor?

—Senator Hill, please. Such a loud and vulgar groan! You do not apparently give some regard to the balance between caring for consumers and caring for shareholders. Madam Deputy President, the braying opposite indicates something—I don't know what; you can't hear it. But there is a balance to be drawn between massive profits and shareholders' returns and consumer and customer consideration. The banks are moving to satisfy the needs of their large customers and more and more disregarding the needs of their small customers—the profit margin is not so much, they are walking.

speech.para: We have just completed a regional employment inquiry of the Senate Employment, Education and Training Committee, which I chaired and which has now changed its name. That regional employment inquiry went all around Australia. Everywhere the story was the same: `Banks have left our small communities and the branches have closed, and behind the bank closures go the small businesses and the money turning over that local consumers will provide.' You know that, and you did not know what to do about it. But the communities are being backed by the Bendigo Bank, for example, which is one of those organisations that is back in there on behalf of small customers.

The concern that we have on this side is that it is not a fair notion to put up a flat charge, as the Commonwealth Bank is proposing. It is going to very dramatically affect people who regularly withdraw small amounts of money from their modest accounts. They are the people we are particularly concerned about, and we are concerned that this government does not care to even chide the banks on it.
The Advertiser, not known as a red rag but as a much more a conservative newspaper, says in its editorial today:
No wonder Australian banks are so unpopular. No wonder there is burgeoning movement to start more accountable new community based banks.
Indeed, Mr Editorial Writer. To continue:
The federal shadow Treasurer, Mr Crean, suggested that the Howard government should act on the matter. Such interventionism would be ill advised—
No surprise! Then it says:

At the same time the Prime Minister, Mr Howard, or the Treasurer, Mr Costello, should sharply remind banks that the government could take such power, and that should it do so it would have public opinion entirely on its side.

This government is hopelessly out of touch with public opinion. You may have passed the barrier and won the election, but you did not take the minds and hearts of the people with you. This bank exercise and your failure to even give a hoot about your community obligation by requiring the banks to address it is going to backfire all over you in no time at all.

You talk about the impacts of the GST and the savings. How can you possibly justify the benefits of the GST because it reduces costs in the banks and at the same time give no regard to the new bank increases?

talk.start.para: —Again we have the Labor Party attacking the government's tax plan. We have had Senator Crowley spending her five minutes talking about banking charges. I remind Senator Crowley and the Senate that with the tax package this government is proposing to reduce banking costs by removing financial institutions duty and debits tax, currently with an aggregate of $2 billion and expected in two years time to be about $2½ billion. We are going to reduce the cost structure for people to do banking.

speech.para: I go back to the general case. Again, the Labor Party have been questioning the Assistant Treasurer today about the $10 billion lower costs for business. That money is going to do two things to business costs. They are going to be substantially reduced and then, through competition in the marketplace, the prices of goods and services are going to come down too. As you all know, the Treasury estimates of the CPI increase is going to be only 1½ per cent.

Another critical thing about the lowered costs for business is the big impact this is going to have on exports. Business costs are going to be lowered by 3.2 per cent in general terms across all business in Australia, but the costs for exporters doing business will be lowered by 3½ per cent. We have been shooting ourselves in the foot in Australia by penalising our exporters and by giving encouragement to importers importing into Australia. We are doing something about that. We are going to give our exporters a free kick. We are going to give them help and encouragement by giving them, through the new tax system, lower costs of 3½ per cent—that is, $4½ billion per annum.

So what is that going to do? It is going to help the adjustment that is required on the current account deficit, which is still a problem here in Australia; but also our tax plan, through the GST, is going to encourage people to save more rather than to consume. So that is also going to help the current account deficit. And it is going to encourage growth and more jobs in the economy.

Just contrast what we are doing and what the government has done with what the ALP did in the last four years of its reign. Did it go out with its tax plan in 1993 and tell the Australian community what it was going to do—that it was going to lift taxes and charges, the total revenue taken in by the government, by 30 per cent? No, it did not tell anyone about that. But that is what it actually did. Not only did it do that; it also went out and borrowed heavily. Over four years of Mr Keating as Prime Minister it went out and borrowed another $70 billion and spent all that as well. It also spent $9 billion that it got from the sale of assets—half of the Commonwealth Bank, Qantas and CSL. It spent 27 per cent of GDP in the last year of the Keating government.

Contrast that with us. What have we done? We have reduced costs. We have reduced the government expenditure in the GDP from 27 per cent in the last year of the Keating government to 25 per cent today. The Commonwealth accounts for 25 per cent of expenditure in the economy. Not only that: we are currently in surplus. In other words, we are living within our means, which is quite a big contrast with what the previous government did. Not only that: we are also reducing Commonwealth government debt. We inherited a Commonwealth debt of about $96 billion, and it has been significantly reduced to date. The government plans to keep reducing that government debt. Furthermore, what did we do with regard to the election? We went out a year before the election—in fact longer—and announced that we were going to go in for tax reform. We went through proper process. We actually had an inquiry, which I had the honour of chairing. We had over 650 submissions. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —Senator Gibson has just spent a fair amount of his time talking about the supposed benefits of a GST to business. Of course, when you hear the bank executives these days, they do not talk about customers; they talk about the benefits to business, the benefits to the bank, and the benefits to shareholders. Senator Gibson, the fact is that a major, if not the essential, role of banks is to serve the needs of its customers. All the bank customers out there, the many hundreds, thousands, millions of depositors in banks—ordinary men and women and their families in this country—know that if there is one thing they are not getting today from banks it is decent, good service. Continually we have seen—and particularly over the last 12 months—a reduction in services, along with an increase in fees and charges.

speech.para: Let us have a look at that record over the 12 months. Senator Knowles likes to talk about 13 years. Let us see what has happened under this government in just 12 months. With respect to the ANZ group, for instance, in the last 12 months only, 175 branches of the ANZ Bank around this country have been closed! At the same time, what has happened to the ANZ's profits? Their profits went up by eight per cent to $1.175 billion in 12 months.

There is not a small depositor or even a medium-sized depositor with the ANZ Bank who has earned anywhere near that percentage amount on their savings. In fact, when most average bank depositors—those who have their pay packet paid in each month or each week, have the normal household expenses and so forth, and have to use banking services—look at their bank statements these days, most of them will find that on the normal average savings and cheque accounts the level of charges is higher than the amount of interest they earn. You will come back and say, `We have got interest rates low.' That may be okay for borrowers but there are a lot of depositors out there who are finding they are paying more to the banks to have access to their money than they are getting by way of return through the small interest that they are earning. Where is the service in that? One hundred and seventy-five branches have closed. Fee income for the ANZ Bank has gone up to $1.5 billion in 12 months.

Whilst we see the impact upon small depositors, families and households around this country, what has happened to the salaries for bank executives? That is a different story. For instance, the Chief Executive Officer of the ANZ Bank earned, in his first year, $1.76 million, and $560,000 of that was a performance bonus. He got paid $560,000 for closing down 175 branches, reducing service!

In answer to a question asked by Senator Conroy, Senator Kemp stated at the end of his comments, `The ultimate policy of the coalition government is to create cheaper and more efficient services.' They are not becoming more efficient. How are they becoming more efficient when hundreds of branches are being closed around this country and bank customers are being shunted out by increasing fees for over the counter services and are being forced more and more to use automatic teller machines? And what have the banks done in the last week or two? They have increased the fees for the use of automatic teller machines. They now want to get customers out of the bank, away from the ATMs and into supermarkets to do their banking through EFTPOS.

Look at the other banks, for instance, the National Australia Bank. The Chief Executive is retiring on $2.7 million and what has been the great performance of that bank over the last 12 months? They closed 71 branches. They reduced the work force by approximately 1,500 people. But their fee income went up by 19 per cent and their profits increased. It is the same story wherever you look at the four major banks. Competition is a myth. It is the customers who are suffering under this government. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —We have had a quite extraordinary attack on the ANZ Bank this afternoon from my colleague Senator Forshaw suggesting that banks do not give a damn about the impact of their charges on families and suggesting that we do not give a damn about it either. Senator Crowley made the suggestion that we do not give a hoot about bank charges and taxes. The extraordinary thing about this is that both of these contributions have come from members of this place who where part of a government which delivered interest rates of up to 21 per cent to farmers, to small business and to families with mortgages.

speech.para: Senator Crowley would know that in our home state of South Australia this led to thousands and thousands of bankruptcies in small businesses. Thousands of farm families lost their farms and many families were forced to sell their properties because they could not pay the bank charges that your economic policies delivered. So when we hear who does not give a hoot about bank charges, to coin a rather unfortunate phrase of Senator Crowley's, we suggest that Senator Crowley and Senator Forshaw, and perhaps some of their colleagues, put a mirror up to their faces and consider for a moment the policies which were delivered by their government to the families of Australia.
Senator Calvert interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Indeed. Gareth's granny frightener—
—Order! Senator Ferris, please refer to members in the other place by their correct titles.

—The member for Holt, Gareth Evans, made a very constructive suggestion for tax reform. He suggested valuations of pre-1985 assets, what is known out in the community as a granny frightener, I believe. Grannies and thousands of other Australians reacted appropriately by voting the opposition down.

speech.para: I would like to read a short and thoughtful piece from a document which members opposite who are still in the chamber may find interesting. It is headed `The Vicious Circle' and says:

The patchwork system this government inherited is riddled with inefficiency and unfairness and is now beyond further patching up. The system has lost the respect of a lot of taxpayers and exploitation of the system is rife.
It's become a vicious circle. Tax rates rise. More people opt out. Then tax rates have to rise again.

Most of my colleagues on this side of the chamber would probably agree with that. Those opposite might be interested to know that this is an excerpt from a contribution that was made as part of the government's guide to tax reform presented at the National Taxation Summit in July 1985 by the government of the day, led by Prime Minister Hawke and Treasurer Paul Keating. There it is, an admission that this taxation system is worn out, inefficient, beyond further patching up and riddled with holes that are being exploited by tax avoiders. What better evidence—out of the mouths of your own people more 10 years ago—can there be that the taxation system needs repair, reform and restoration to give a fairer and greater opportunity to families, to enjoy a greater amount of spending money and discretionary spending, so that they are taxed when they spend and not taxed when they earn?

As all roads lead to Rome when policies are being discussed on your side of the chamber, I suggest all roads lead to Werriwa. You only need to have a look at what the member for Werriwa has been suggesting the opposition should do when looking at taxation. I will end my contribution by simply saying that Labor needs once again to take policy seriously, not just to use it as a campaign convenience, not something to be picked up and thrown away. Some of you might like to have another look at A Guide to Taxation Reform of 1985. There is great policy in there. If you took it on board you would realise, as we do and as the population of Australia do, that taxation reform is needed. (Time expired).
Question resolved in the affirmative.

talk.start.para: —I would like to table a short statement in relation to the return to order motion that has just been defeated.
—I lay on the table the Scrutiny of Bills Alert Digest No. 10 of 1998 dated 25 November 1998.

—In accordance with the provisions of the Auditor-General Act 1997, I present the following report of the Auditor-General: Report No. 17 of 1998-99—Performance Audit—Acquisition of Aerospace Simulators: Department of Defence .

interjection.para: Senator MARGETTS (Western Australia) (4.02 p.m.) (by leave)—I move:
That the Senate take note of the document.

I would like to draw the attention of honourable senators to the recommendations from the Auditor-General and to the findings that there do not seem to be any actual policies relating to the acquisition and use of aerospace simulators for training when expensive pieces of equipment—new aircraft—are ordered.

I would like to speak on this issue at greater length on a future occasion but, for now, I will just say that it is worth looking at the report and at the fact that perhaps this is a pattern that has been repeated in other areas of the Australian Defence Force. There did not seem to be a specific policy on the acquisition and choice of simulators, including on their design and specifications, and the use of them in training as a money saving device. We are talking about billions of dollars, potentially. We are also talking about the availability of aircraft and amenities for communities where training aircraft are used rather than simulators.

I think it is worth while alerting honourable senators and the community to the document because it does fit in with a lot of the concerns people have in general about the acquisition policies of the Australian Defence Force and the need for integrated policies that are effective in spending public money. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
