talk.start.para: —Order! It being nearly 7.20 p.m., I propose the question:

interjection.para: That the Senate do now adjourn.

talk.start.para: —As the Senate would be aware, there has been a resurgence of student demonstrations in Indonesia which left 14 dead at the hands of the army and hundreds wounded. Now, with the news this week of Muslim mobs attacking Christian churches and lynching Christians, it is fair evidence to what degree our neighbouring country has disintegrated. Indonesia's economic and political turmoil is a legacy of the Suharto regime. In a short space of time the Indonesian facade, which the Australian government has hailed for 20 years or more, has disintegrated into a poverty stricken country on the political precipice.

speech.para: It is true to say that much of Australia's thinking over those years was designed to avoid the consequences of an archipelago with the multitude of ethnic communities and religions at war with each other, the consequences of which are obvious. The cornerstone of Australia's foreign policy towards Indonesia over the last 20 years plus has been designed to avoid this possibility. Our foreign policy therefore gravitated to the Suharto regime, which it was believed would deliver a politically and economically secure Indonesia. But, like all good foreign policies based on self-interest, a balance is needed. And on any analysis, Australia lost its balance.

Within a generation, the policy has been shown to be a failure. Australia too frequently turned a blind eye to the corruption and only whispered its dissent to human rights abuses. For all this neighbourly bonding we saw nothing coming—not the economic, social or political collapse. The foreign policy we spent decades manicuring can hardly be said to have built up any useful insight into Indonesia. For all the achievements the department of foreign affairs would claim from their softly, softly relationship over the past 20 years, the lack of achievement has been greater. Just look at today's results. The truth is that the Suharto regime ploughed on regardless, without meaningful political, social or economic reform.

Now that fundamentally the power of the day has gone up in smoke, Australia's foreign policy requires a new approach to deal with the new circumstances. Ironically, given the precarious situation Indonesia finds itself in, a softly, softly approach is more relevant now than it was then. I accept that we must understand the dilemma the new government finds itself in. On one hand, law and order must be preserved and minorities protected from the street rioters; on the other hand, the military presence on the street must be kept from turning into brutal repression. Provided the new government of Indonesia is moving towards major reform, we should understand their dilemma and tailor our responses accordingly. Yet this is no time, nor any excuse, to diminish any effort to resolve the East Timor question. In fact, it has never been more timely for Australia to reassess its foreign policy regarding East Timor.

I urge a reassessment involving a stronger stance for a free East Timor—one that is more aligned to the international community and, more particularly, the United Nations. All the old arguments used to sustain Indonesia's occupation of East Timor are now either well and truly outdated or irrelevant to the emerging Indonesia of today. For exam ple, the claim that Indonesia's invasion and continued occupation has been necessary to prevent a little Cuba developing can no longer stand. Perhaps in 1975, at the height of the Cold War, this had some validity. With the end of the Cold War, the tagging of East Timor as a little Cuba can no longer be justified. Another example is the claim that the Portuguese were `lousy colonisers' who are now just in it for themselves and therefore have no right to reclaim their colony. This has been debunked by the fact that Portugal does not seek to recolonise. Rather, they are pushing for a free East Timor at the United Nations—at the request of the East Timorese.

I believe the following steps are needed to increase pressure on the Indonesian government to accelerate a resolution of the East Timor question. First, support East Timorese participation at the United Nations-sponsored peace talks between Portugal and Indonesia. Second, Australia should offer to play a greater financial and administrative role in the United Nations-sponsored peace talks. Third, Australia should establish a consulate in East Timor which would enhance the monitoring of human rights abuses. Fourth, Australia should forge closer relations with the Portuguese government thereby dispelling the international perception that Australia may have a biased approach to the East Timor question. Fifth, seek the release of Xanana Gusmao. Sixth, maintain, into the foreseeable future, the suspension of military exercises with the Indonesian armed forces. This would maintain the pressure for meaningful progress on the Indonesian government. Seventh, support an Indonesian-Australian inquiry into the 1975 deaths of the five Australian journalists at Balibo. Those responsible must be brought to account for their crimes, as much for the sake of the families as for Australia's own code of justice.

I concede that if Australia were to do any immediate backflip on its foreign policy towards East Timor, it could definitely confuse the Indonesians and, perhaps, even create a hostile neighbour. So I am not asking for a backflip or a great leap of change in our foreign policy. But I believe, for the reasons I have given, that we need a definite shift in our foreign policy.

subdebateinfo.title: Banking: Local Government and Regional Australia

talk.start.para: —I thank Senator McGauran for making some very interesting remarks. Tonight I would like to talk briefly about banking services, local government and regional Australia. On 20 June 1996 the Treasurer, Peter Costello, told the House of Representatives that:

speech.para: If there is any suggestion of anti-competitive activity or collusion in fees and charges, the government does have the option of referring the matter to the relevant body, the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission. And we will take that action if necessary, or if any information arises of inadequate competition in that area of products as well.
Yesterday, in response to calls for the government to take action on what seems to be exponentially increasing bank fees, Senator Rod Kemp said:
Bank customers can maximise the benefits of competition by actively shopping around for the best products, services and prices to satisfy their needs.

It seems that these two statements, at worst, directly contradict each other and, at best, seem completely different. The latest line from the government seems to be that if customers are not happy with bank fees, bank closures and loss of services around the country, then they should simply swap banks.

This government—or, certainly, Senator Kemp in relation to the remarks he made—clearly has no real understanding of the terrible impact of bank closures on regional Australian communities. Many people in regional Australia now have no choice at all when it comes to banking, which makes the concept of shopping around a bit senseless. More and more communities are losing their basic banking services, and the Prime Minister simply mouths platitudes of sympathy whilst no action is taken.
Regional Australians can only be offended by the Prime Minister's statement to the National Farmers Federation last night, reported in the Australian Financial Review today. He said:

Another matter I want to acknowledge is the great concern in rural Australia about the disappearance of services. Some of these services, the loss of them, has been very painful, and some of it is unavoidable and some is irreversible.
The final insult was his claim that he was:
very conscious of the concern within rural Australia about the presence of bank branches.

I would interpolate there the `lack' of presence of bank branches. Under the Howard government in 1997-98 we have seen approximately 500 bank branches close. Yet the government still claims that customers can shop around and that competition will ultimately sort it out. But that clearly is not happening.

One particularly significant sector that has expressed deep concern about continuing closures, particularly in the face of large profits for the banks, is local government. And those profits are enormous, as a number of senators have alluded to today. The big four earned a pre-tax profit of $6.29 billion this year. Perhaps this government has not heard clearly enough the message on banking which has been coming from local government over the last year. After all, it is clear from the tax package, which seeks to rid the Commonwealth of any direct relationship with local government, that councils and their communities do not seem to rate very highly on this government's agenda.

The government has consistently ignored local government and clearly underestimates its importance to the community with regard to a range of issues. Despite the ongoing protestations from the Australian Local Government Association, the government has effectively washed its hands of any real responsibility and any national approach to local government by proposing to hand over responsibility for local government funding to the states—something which is regarded with deep trepidation, particularly by local councils in Victoria. They propose handing local government to the states with little, if any, consultation and no guarantee that funding will be improved, or even maintained, in the long term. There has not been a clear signal from the government with respect to that. It is also clear that the coalition has not yet listened to local government with regard to tax reform, and there is no indication that they will. But local government has expressed great concern about the continuing withdrawal of services from regional Australia. In fact, it has been voicing its concern for quite some time.

In 1997, the General Assembly of Local Government, a gathering of over 700 councillors from around Australia, considered the issue of regional banking services. Earlier this year the Australian Local Government Association made a submission to the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Financial Institutions and Public Administration inquiry into banking services in regional Australia. In its submission, the ALGA said:

While government may not have a direct role in maintaining banking services, it has one in ensuring that the outcomes of commercial decisions of business reflect adequately the needs of rural Australia and take account of the intrinsic values of community and diversity.
`Hear, Hear!' we all say. ALGA pointed out that the issue was a matter of both:
. equity of access to services for those Australians whose circumstances dictate a life outside the major urban centres of the nation; and
. Maintenance of the viability of rural local communities in the name of diversity and their intrinsic value.
At the recent General Assembly of Local Government, which I was pleased to be able to attend, a motion on banking services was carried. That motion reads:

The Australian Local Government Association calls on the Federal Government to obligate banks to return to providing banking services to towns throughout regional Australia, particularly in view of the large profits of the four major banks and the large number of towns that have lost banking services and the associated socioeconomic problems which have occurred as a result.

The situation has got so serious—not just in regional Australia but in the cities as well—that local government in NSW seriously considered withdrawing some $4.4 billion worth of business from `recalcitrant banks' and depositing these revenues with community friendly financial institutions. So effectively they are considering voting with their feet. Local government has shown that it is very concerned about the effect bank closures have on its local communities, but this government does not seem to care. This government stands by while banks increase their fees and continue to close services.

What are communities to do in these circumstances? Certainly, shopping around in many small towns where there is only one bank is, as I indicated, simply not an option. Once again, if the government actually did listen to local government it might get a few ideas. The General Assembly of Local Government also addressed what to do when banks do close. Their motion reads:

The Australian Local Government Association calls upon the Federal Government to negotiate an agreement with the Australian Bankers Association to develop protocols concerning the closure of any bank, and in particular those branches located in rural and regional Australia. Such protocols take account of the social and economic impacts on communities, including:
. Alternative Service Provision
. Training in other banking techniques (telebanking, giro payments, ATM network development, links to Credit Union Partnership arrangements and such like);
. Consideration of Agency/Joint Venture Service provision.

Local government knows what happens when banks withdraw from communities. Appearing before the House of Representatives banking inquiry last year, a representative of the Tasmanian Local Government Association illustrated the impact very clearly. He said:

Importantly, when people travel to larger centres to utilise their banking services, they also conduct other business there. There is a drop, therefore in consumer spending with local businesses in rural municipalities resulting in a loss of jobs and out-migration of households and businesses This would be likely to result in a reversal of any previous intentions to take out loans for investment in local business and thereby impeding development of small enterprises. Therefore, a loss or reduction in the full range of banking services could impede the viability of rural communities and place them in jeopardy.

I do not think I could have put it better myself. Unlike this government, the Labor Party recognised the deleterious impact of bank closures on regional Australian communities. Prior to the election we thought long and hard about our policy development process and we committed to:
. Develop a Charter of Regional Banking Responsibility to define the obligations to rural and remote communities which banks should reasonably be prepared to meet;

. Encourage voluntary arrangements to provide banking services; and Ensure that through a Regional Banking Services Fund (contributed to by all licensed banks) services are maintained and restored where justifiable.

We knew we were pretty much right on the button when the banks screamed the house down, particularly in relation to that latter point. Will the coalition match that? Will the coalition do anything about it? At the moment, despite the immense coverage that this issue is getting, nothing seems to be emanating from the government. We need action on this. Local government knows that government cannot just stand around and watch from the sidelines as local communities are hit by bank fee increases and bank closures. Why doesn't the government seem to understand this? We call on the government to take action in this regard.

talk.start.para: —I wish to expand on some of the points I made on Monday, 23 November 1998 concerning the critical issue of claims by the executive to the commercial-in-confidence ground for refusing to produce documents requested by the Senate. Senators will recall that in a tabling statement accompanying documents in response to a Return to Order, the Leader of the Government claimed that it was `in accord with Senate practice' that certain documents are withheld. Of course, such a claim is baseless. The Senate may decide at its discretion that certain documents should not be made public, but it is not at the discretion of the executive that such a decision is made. To do so is for the executive to usurp the crucial role of scrutiny of government that the Senate performs and that all parliaments perform as a democratic and public duty.

speech.para: It is time the Senate bit the bullet with respect to this issue. Recent academic, judicial and media comment all follow the same theme that members of the executive must not be able to ignore requests by upper houses for information with impunity. I will provide examples of such comment shortly. The point is that the climate is now right for a Senate challenge to such an arrogant use of executive power or, perhaps, to put it more correctly, such arrogant use of purported executive power, as it is not clear that refusal to produce documents in the face of a valid order by the Senate is within the constitutional power of the executive. We all know that the executive does exercise this power at present. My point is that they do it without authority.
In their joint judgment in the recent High Court case of Egan v. Willis, Justices Gaudron, Gummow and Hayne described the relationship between the executive and the parliament as follows:

A system of responsible government traditionally has been considered to encompass the means by which Parliament brings the Executive to account so that the Executive's primary responsibility in its prosecution of government is owed to Parliament. The point was made by Mill, writing in 1861, who spoke of the task of the legislature to watch and control the government: to throw the light of publicity on its acts. It has been said of the contemporary position in Australia that, whilst the primary role of Parliament is to pass laws, it also has important functions to question and criticise government on behalf of the people and that to secure accountability of government activity is the very essence of responsible government.

That is about as unequivocal an endorsement that I could get for the position of myself and my party on this issue, and that endorsement is from the highest court of this country. This judgment sends a clear signal to the executive that it cannot simply ignore the structures set up by our constitution and its conventions for the proper and transparent conduct of government.
Further judicial support comes from the unanimous judgment in the 1997 Lange case. Here the High Court directly addressed the issue of the reach of executive power in the following terms:

Those provisions which prescribe the system of responsible government necessarily imply a limitation on legislative and executive power to deny the electors and their representatives information concerning the conduct of the Executive Branch of Government throughout the life of a Federal Parliament.
Thus the court highlights a constitutional limitation on the power of the executive to withhold information from this house.

In a valuable analysis of claims to commercial-in-confidence by the executive at federal level, Tom Brennan, a partner in Corrs Chambers Wesgarth, in a paper entitled `Undertakings of confidence by the Commonwealth: are there limits?' in 1998 argues that arrangements entered into by the executive that involve undertakings of confidence may be void as being beyond power. He says on this point:

Where the information concerned is material to the operation of government, it is inconsistent with the responsibility of the Executive to the Parliament for the Executive to enter into enforceable obligations of confidence which would prevent such disclosures to the Parliament . . . The Executive does not have the power to enter into an obligation with such an effect.
Brennan further suggests that `parliamentary privilege law would suggest that the executive could not refuse to comply with a requirement of either house that such information be provided'.

It is therefore clear that the weight of legal analysis is in the corner of the Senate on this issue. Therefore, if the Labor Party's partisan interest in this issue—and that partisan interest is with their keeping one eye out for what might impede their own executive power when they get their turn in office—can be put aside for just a short time, this house would be on solid legal ground by imposing appropriate penalties for a repeat of the executive's contempt of the Senate as exemplified by its response to the return to order to which I have referred.

But we would not only be acting soundly in a legal sense but also in the public good in enforcing accountability in the eyes of commentators and the public. In his column of 24 November 1998 in the Bulletin, for example, Laurie Oakes states:

Executive control is a major reason for the decline in the status of Australian Parliaments. And it is a solid argument for not tampering with the system that allows the Senate to act as real parliaments should be holding governments accountable and subjecting their policies and actions to proper scrutiny . . . Only in the Senate—thanks to minor parties and Independents—is the power of a bloated executive ever challenged.
Further, in an editorial in the Australian newspaper of 20 November 1998, the writer says of claims to commercial confidentiality:

This defence is over-used by governments trying to avoid scrutiny and embarrassment and often represents arrogance of the first order: a democracy elects its representatives to act on behalf of the electorate as a whole, not of vested interests. The system requires the utmost transparency and direct accountability from its parliamentary representatives. Lack of transparency and limiting the capacity of Parliament to review government decisions weaken our democracy.

Election results federally and in the states clearly reflect a desire by the Australian people to have independent upper houses that act as a check on the executive. But in order to carry out this desire of the people, upper houses must demand, and get, full disclosure on government dealings.

Given the weight of opinion on this issue, and the recent experience in New South Wales, where only legal action would bring the executive to the table to resolve the issue, it is time for this house to send a clear signal to the federal executive that further defiance of Senate orders will result in the appropriate penalty being applied. It appears that only by such action will the Senate get the disclosure it needs to carry out its constitutionally and electorally ordained role.

talk.start.para: —I rise tonight to pay tribute to a great Victorian and indeed a great Australian. I pay tribute to Sir John Buchan, community activist, business leader and political pillar. He was a civic leader in the true sense of the word; imbued with a sense of duty and altruism. He was a visionary. John Buchan left behind a wonderful legacy—a legacy that most people could not accumulate in a dozen lifetimes. There were many who knew him better and longer than I. That I knew him at all, and felt his support and patronage, is an honour and a privilege.

speech.para: There are many others who have paid Sir John Buchan more eloquent tributes than I can, but I am proud to say that, along with another great former Liberal Party president, Michael Kroger, Sir John agreed to be my referee for my preselection to this place on two occasions. I hope and pray that my contribution to the parliament will do him proud. I am honoured to be able to rise in this place to pay him tribute tonight.

Sir John Buchan's achievements were many; his life dedicated to the service of other people. There were so many aspects to Sir John's life. He was undoubtedly a great architect and business leader, one who headed, for 40 years, what is today one of Australia's largest, oldest and most respected architectural practices.

He had an indelible influence on Melbourne's landscape. He is credited with providing the catalyst and vision for Melbourne's great South Bank development—a vital and vibrant landmark that will be part of Melbourne for many generations to come. Under the auspices of the Soldier Settlement Scheme, he built over 2,000 homes across Victoria to house returned servicemen. The Stock Exchange building, the Russell Defence Complex here in Canberra, Jupiters Casino, shopping complexes and many other fine Victorian and Australian landmarks all bear Sir John's creative mark.

He was co-founder of Apex Australia, with its origins in Geelong as the Geelong Young Businessmen's Club. It was formed in the shadow and pain of the First World War and the Great Depression. It was formed because of the compassion and vision of three friends. John Buchan was just 20 at the time. In his own words:
It was post-depression. We felt we had jobs, albeit minor ones, and here was an opportunity to do something for young men by bringing them together in some form of fellowship and service.

Apex's emblem, no doubt, is well known to all of us. The three equal sides represent the great qualities of citizenship, fellowship and service for others. The triangle and name represent the scaling of great heights and the rays are symbolic of the rising generation of youth. This emblem could well be a metaphor for John Buchan's life. Apex has gone on to become a national and an international institu tion dedicated to the service of others. Sir John did the same.

John Buchan served his country with distinction in Greece, the Middle East and Africa during World War II, reaching the rank of captain. He served on the Melbourne City Council from 1954 to 1959 and had an important impact on town planning and local governance issues. He also served on the boards of the Royal Melbourne Hospital and La Trobe University.

He went on to become President of the Victorian Liberal Party of Australia from 1958 to 1962 and then its Treasurer from 1962 to 1967. He counted amongst his close friends and confidants Sir Robert Menzies, Sir Henry Bolte and Lord Casey. He could pick up the telephone to Roosevelt and Nixon. He was critical in forging a strong and vibrant Liberal Party in Victoria.

He loved all things American, not least his charming wife, Lady Virginia, and became state and then federal president of the Australian-American Association. In 1971 Sir John was knighted in recognition of his contribution to international relations, in particular between Australia and the USA.

Sir John was always in for the long haul. Whether it was the Southbank project, which took over 20 years to come to fruition, or youth unemployment, Sir John did not allow any setback to diminish his enthusiasm or tenacity.

Ted Baillieu provided a moving tribute to Sir John at his memorial service. With Sir John, Ted shares the distinction of being a great former president of the Victorian division, an architect and a Geelong Football Club supporter. Ted observed that if John Buchan was guilty of an obsession then it was his commitment to the next generation, his faith in the future, his trust in the young.

Despite our mutual involvement in the Liberal Party, it was our mutual concern for the unemployed which forged our relationship. In 1984, two years after his retirement, Sir John founded the National Committee for Development of Youth Employment—a group that had as its members six knights, a major-general and six heads of some of Australia's biggest companies. It was typical of Sir John to draw on his business and political contacts for a worthy cause and in his mind there was no worthier cause than tackling youth unemployment. The committee did not shirk from the difficult questions and combined practical on-the-ground solutions with hard-hitting policy recommendations, not least among them calling for a review of youth wages and legalising voluntary work contracts. Back in the mid-1980s he talked of community service in return for the dole.

His passion for the unemployed in his final years was JANA—Jobs A New Approach, established in country Victoria with Sir John ambitiously planning for a national expansion. JANA embraced all that Sir John believed in. It calls upon members of service clubs, who are so fortunate in life, to share their experience, time and skills with those less fortunate. Just as Sir John had mentored so many in his own life, he was challenging others to do the same.

Sir John knew that we would only ever start to come to grips with unemployment when government, community and business worked together. In the past four years alone, there are over 500 young people who have jobs and hope, thanks to Sir John's vision, compassion and drive.

Just weeks before his death, inevitably in the first week of the election campaign, I spoke with Sir John. We spoke naturally enough of politics and of the deservedness of another coalition victory. He encouraged me during a difficult personal and political time. As with every conversation we had, it turned to our mutual concern about unemployment. At 89 years of age, Sir John was still searching for ways to respond positively to the tragedy of youth unemployment and pondering what impact the forthcoming election would have on thousands of young people.

Characteristically, we talked about who he should lobby next. No minister, Prime Minister, industry or community leader was immune from his phone calls or letters. The conversation with Sir John was typical of him—warm, encouraging, optimistic and a bit cheeky.

Sir John may have retired from work but he never retired from life or from the service of his community. He was filled with an indomitable spirit and a great love for humanity. Sir John was a great man but, more importantly, he was a good man.

Victoria lost a great leader and a great citizen with the passing of Sir John on 25 October, and those who were honoured to be part of his world, in some small way, will miss him greatly. To his gracious and beautiful wife, Lady Virginia, and to his children, Susan, Tom and Debbie, may I express my heartfelt sympathy.
As one of the many tributes printed in newspapers around the country over the past month said, `Put simply, Buchan made Australia a better place in which to live.'
